headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Zions Bancorporation's Fourth Quarter 2015 Earning Results Webcast Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this call is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to Jame
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Zions Bancorporation's Fourth Quarter 2015 Earning Results Webcast Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this call is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to James Abbott, Director of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good evening. We welcome you to this conference call to discuss our fourth quarter 2015 earnings. Our primary participants today will be Harris Simmons, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; Scott McLean, President and Chief Operating Offic
componenttext:
Thank you, and good evening. We welcome you to this conference call to discuss our fourth quarter 2015 earnings. Our primary participants today will be Harris Simmons, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; Scott McLean, President and Chief Operating Officer; and Paul Burdiss, Chief Financial Officer.
I would like to remind you that during this call, we will be making forward-looking statements although actual results may differ materially. We encourage you to review the disclaimer in this press release dealing with forward-looking information, which applies equally to statements made in this call.
A full copy of the earnings release will be -- as well as the supplemental slide deck are available at zionsbancorporation.com. We will be referring to the slides during this call. We intend to limit the length of this call to 1 hour, which will include a question-and-answer section. [Operator Instructions] I will now turn the time over to Harris Simmons.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, James, and welcome to all of you who are on the call today to discuss our fourth quarter and full year 2015 results.There's obviously a lot of focus on energy, and we'll talk about energy as we get further into the presentation. But I want to
componenttext:
Thank you, James, and welcome to all of you who are on the call today to discuss our fourth quarter and full year 2015 results.
There's obviously a lot of focus on energy, and we'll talk about energy as we get further into the presentation. But I want to talk about a variety of things that we think are actually working very nicely before we get to that.
On Slide 3 in the related slides that we distributed, we've tried to highlight some of the initiatives that are working well or within our expectations. I'll touch on a few of these in my remarks here, but as an overarching comment, I would want to say that I am quite encouraged with the positive operating leverage that we achieved in the quarter. The positive revenue trajectory, the stable expense levels and solid progress that we've made on the technology project that we're pursuing. 
We are highly focused on improving the profitability and growth profile of the company, and we made very tangible progress in 2015 towards those goals. Additionally, despite the weakness in energy commodity prices, we are able to maintain strong overall asset quality metrics, and we experienced an encouraging improvement in the rate of loan growth compared to the prior quarter during the fourth quarter here. 
On Slide 4, we display our loans and deposits. Relative to the third quarter, we experienced improved loan growth in the fourth quarter at $536 million or about 5% annualized. Excluding the effects of expected energy loan attrition, loan growth was more than $700 million or about 8% annualized. 
We were pleased with growth in areas that are targeted for growth, specifically non-energy commercial and industrial and consumer loans. Deposit growth shown in the chart on the right has been a strong story for Zions for quite some time, and the source of that growth has come primarily from the most viable source, which is noninterest-bearing deposits. The value of those deposits should increase as rates rise and should lead to a strong increase in earnings if and when interest rates further increased. Thus far, we've been able to hold deposit rates quite flat.
Turning to Slide 5. The most significant source of revenue for Zions is net interest income, which equals about 78% of the fourth quarter net revenue. Although a portion of the increase from the prior quarter was driven by interest income recoveries that may not occur in the first quarter of 2016, we expect the interest rate increase in December will offset that factor. Also driving net interest income higher was the increase in both loans and securities as well as the material reduction in interest paid on debt. Accordingly, we expect we'll experience similar, if not slightly higher, net interest income in the first quarter of 2016.
On Slide 6, we were encouraged with the results from the initiatives we've made to grow fee income. Managed fee income increased 4% from the 2014 year, and we are targeting a stronger growth rate in 2016. Managed fee income is defined by assets income sources we manage directly and exclude the effect of dividends, securities gains and losses and other similar sources. 
The most significant increase in 2015 was from treasury management, which increased 13%. It also happens to be our strongest contributor to total fee income. Some of the headwinds include loan fees, which were down due in part to soft demand for energy lending as well as overdraft fees, which is attributable at least in part to strengthening consumer balance sheets. 
On Slide 7, we have the cost savings initiative scorecard graph, with the bar on the left illustrating the commitment to achieve $120 million of gross cost savings by the end of 2017. The bar on the right illustrating the cost saves that were accomplished in 2015. We remain on track to achieve the targeted cost reductions by 2017, having already realized more than half of the goal by the end of 2015. 
We're encouraged with the achievement of holding noninterest expense to less than $1.6 billion in 2015. Additionally, our commitment is to hold that line item, adjusted for certain restructuring costs, to below $1.6 billion in 2016. We expect benefits in 2016 to include the simplification of operations that are due in part to the charter consolidation.
Moving to Slide 8. We have achieved a portion of another key measure of our commitment to shareholders, which was to reduce the efficiency ratio to 70% or below in the second half of 2015. We're encouraged with this achievement, and we are reiterating our commitment to achieve an efficiency ratio in 2016 of 66% or better as well as those other targets that we first communicated on June 1 of last year.
On Slide 9, we are satisfied with the progress we have made on our technology projects. The general ledger transition and new reporting tool conversion are complete. The credit approval workflow system software is installed in most of our banks, with the completion scheduled for the spring of this year. The same is true for the enterprise loan operations. We're tracking for a spring completion. 
Regarding our core systems replacement project, which we've dubbed Future Core and where we've partnered with Tata Consultancy Services, we're expecting a consumer loan system to roll out later this year, with commercial lending tracking for 2017 and the deposits scheduled for 2018. In summary, we are making significant investments to provide a very strong technology foundation for the future. These are investments that will simplify our operating environment and give us the ability to be highly competitive in an industry where technology is obviously playing an increasingly important role.
Finally, as noted in the press release, the consolidation of our 7 subsidiary banks to a single national bank charter was completed on December 31. We'll continue to emphasize our locally-oriented leadership structure and the power of our strong local brand in each market we serve. And we'll find some additional efficiency from this consolidation of charters. We're very optimistic about the future operational and financial performance for Zions.
With that brief overview, I'll turn the call over to Paul Burdiss to review the financial results. Paul?

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Harris, and good afternoon, everyone. I'll begin on Slide 10. For the fourth quarter of 2015, Zions reported net earnings to common shareholders of $88 million or $0.43 per share. Relative to the third quarter, net interest income increased abo
componenttext:
Thank you, Harris, and good afternoon, everyone. I'll begin on Slide 10. For the fourth quarter of 2015, Zions reported net earnings to common shareholders of $88 million or $0.43 per share. Relative to the third quarter, net interest income increased about 5.5%. 
Adjusted for recoveries of interest income and a linked-quarter increase in income from loans purchased from the FDIC, net interest income increased just under 3%. Actively managed noninterest income, which excludes investment-related items like security gains and losses, increased slightly from the prior quarter, and as Harris mentioned earlier, increased about 4% for the full year 2015 when compared to the full year in 2014. 
At just over $400 million, noninterest expenses were higher in the fourth quarter when compared to the third quarter due in part to elevated levels of expenses in certain categories as detailed in the press release, which accompanied this call. We are encouraged by the efforts of our teammates to manage our cost of doing business. Our collective efforts allow Zions to realize our goal of adjusted noninterest expense at less than $1.6 billion for 2015.
Turning to the provision for loan and lease losses. We had expected a moderate build and the reserve for energy loans partially offset by continued reserve release [indiscernible] in the portfolio. Although throughout most of the quarter, we expected the provision for loan losses to be in line with the third quarter results, the decline in the price of oil near the end of the quarter resulted in a moderately higher provision. The energy loan portfolio continued to perform about as we had expected. 
As we progress through 2016, we expect quarterly provisions to be moderately higher than the fourth quarter results. The key driver of our expectation for an elevated provision in 2016 is lower prevailing energy prices. Actual results may therefore vary from expectations if energy prices remain volatile. 
Finally, I would like to highlight the return on tangible common equity. Although we are working to drive shareholder returns to a much higher level, I'll point out that our efforts over the past year have resulted in a better than 100 basis point increase in shareholder return when compared to the same period a year ago, while capital levels have actually increased slightly during the period.
Turning to Slide 11, I'll address some of the drivers of net interest income, beginning with volume. Details of our investment portfolio are shown here on Slide 11. We have been adding securities to our investment portfolio for the past year or so, reflecting the need for a permanent high-quality liquid asset position in order to manage our balance sheet liquidity more effectively and in light of the recently established liquidity coverage ratio rules. 
Our efforts to build out the investment portfolio are expected to add revenue in the current and downside economic environment when compared to holding liquidity in the form of cash. During the fourth quarter, we added $1.5 billion to our investment securities portfolio on average when compared to the third quarter. In light of the general market expectation for rising short-term rates, we are exercising caution with respect to the impact on overall balance sheet interest rate sensitivities as we purchase fixed-rate investments and duration extension risk inherent in the investment portfolio. 
The securities we are adding are relatively short in duration, just over 3 years. The duration of the entire securities portfolio is estimated to be 2.9 years today. If rates were to rise 200 basis points across the curve, our models indicate that the duration of the portfolio would extend only slightly to about 3.1 years. As expected, the addition of these fixed-rate investments reduced Zion sensitivity somewhat as shown in the table at the bottom right of the page. 
Worth noting the deposit assumptions employed in our [indiscernible] case are, in fact, faster than what we are seeing in the market today, or in plain language, our scenario model assumer faster deposit repricing than we are currently observing in the market. So the improvement in net interest income from the December rate hike could and likely will be higher than that shown in the table on Slide 11.
On Page 12, we break down year-over-year loan growth. Overall, we are encouraged with our fourth quarter loan growth despite some headwinds, as Harris mentioned earlier. Compared to the prior quarter, period end loans grew at a little over 5% annualized. Net commercial and industrial loan growth for the last year was about 6% when excluding the effect of energy loan attrition. It is important to note that we have accomplished this growth without an adverse change in our underwriting standards. 
Year-over-year, net churn commercial real estate growth was about 8% when removing the effect of national real estate portfolio. Residential mortgage continues to be a major focus for growth across our geographic footprint. The other category experienced healthy growth from subcategories such as home equity and municipal lending.
The 2 portfolios that have been in decline for the past year or more are the national real estate portfolio and the energy portfolios. Financial real estate portfolio represents about 6% of loans, and the attrition here resulted in a drag of just over 1 percentage point to the overall growth of the loan portfolio during the past year. The rate of decline is slowing for this portfolio, and it currently accounts for less than 50% of tangible common equity. 
The energy portfolio attrition is well-documented as we have discussed this regularly during the past year, and our outlook remains consistent. We expect continued attrition as our clients actively work through the current environment for energy prices. To summarize, our outlook on loan growth for the next 12 months is for a slightly to moderately increasing portfolio, which should be in the low to mid-single-digit rate of growth range.
Another key component of net interest income, which is the yield or on the portfolio [indiscernible] can be found on Slide 13. This slide key components of our net interest margin, the top line is the loan yield, which increased 6 basis points from the second quarter to average 4.24%. As described in the press release, there was a recovery of interest income of about $8 million included in the fourth quarter loan yield. Excluding this recovery, the loan yields on the portfolio declined about 2 basis points from the prior quarter. 
The securities portfolio yield declined slightly this quarter, largely due to the changing composition of the portfolio as we add new bonds within our guidelines for duration and extension risk. At the bottom of the chart is a line depicting our cost of funds as a percent of earning assets, which continues to be quite low and declined slightly from the prior quarter due to the redemption of high-cost subordinated debt. The net interest margin increased to 3.23%, a 12 basis point increase from the third quarter.
And adjusted for the income recovery, the net interest margin would have been about 3.18%. This increase is largely attributable to the change in earning asset mix, more loans and securities in the fourth quarter and less cash as well as the previously mentioned reduction of high-cost subordinated debt.
Slide 14 provides more detail on loan yields, specifically, the coupon and loan production [indiscernible] portfolio, which we believe is helpful in understanding the risk of future yield on loans and current interest rate environment. The yellow line reflects the GAAP yield on the portfolio. The primary reason for this increase is the previously mentioned interest recovery. 
Importantly, the weighted average coupon of loan portfolio has been stable over the past couple of quarters. The coupon, of course, excludes the effect of amortizing fees, discounts and premiums. The yield on new production also stabilized in the fourth quarter as we saw the yield on larger loans improved somewhat in December, reflective of the moving LIBOR. Although our loan officers are seeing some pricing pressure in the small loan space, our production coupons have been stable.
Turning to credit quality on Slide 15. I'll be brief and say that we continue to experience generally strong credit quality performance in both geographies and segments, with the notable exception of energy-related loans, which are included in our C&I segment. Our reserve for credit loss is quite strong at just under 1.7% of loans, which is nearly 2x our nonperforming assets and over a decade worth of charge-offs based on the fourth quarter annualized results. Despite an increase in classified energy-related loans of just under -- I'm sorry, just over $76 million from the prior quarter level, overall classified loans increased only $45 million or 3% in the fourth quarter. 
Nonperforming assets declined slightly from the prior quarter. Net charge-offs declined due to recoveries, which were $32 million for the fourth quarter of 2015. Gross charge-offs were relatively stable when compared to the prior quarter. Our outlook for 2016 net charge-offs is between 30 and 35 basis points of average loans. The majority of these charge-offs are expected to be energy-related. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Scott to discuss energy lending and the Houston market more broadly.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Paul, and I'll start on Slide 17. Without repeated the table that we have in our earnings release on Page 4 of the earnings release in this -- in the main section of this slide deck can be found in the appendix, but let me just make some summar
componenttext:
Thank you, Paul, and I'll start on Slide 17. Without repeated the table that we have in our earnings release on Page 4 of the earnings release in this -- in the main section of this slide deck can be found in the appendix, but let me just make some summary comments. 
As noted in the press release, energy loan outstandings and commitments declined fairly substantially from the prior quarter and from a year ago. We commented that we believe this would happen throughout 2015. The decline in outstandings was about $450 million compared to a year ago, and commitments are down approximately $1 billion since a year ago. 
Classified energy loan balances increased by approximately $76 million from the prior quarter and finished at a level that is actually somewhat better than what we would have expected a year ago. Nonaccrual energy loans declined from the prior quarter, primarily due to net charge-offs, which is not the way you want to reduce that bucket, but it's important to note that the level did not increase much if you adjust for net charge-offs.
Turning to Slide 16. Let's see, it's not Slide 16. Slide 17. Yes. As we noted since late 2014, we have been extremely active in managing the energy portfolio, including the full attention of our entire executive team, reviewing the portfolio frequently on a credit-by-credit basis plus significant interaction with our customers. Based upon that input, along with our models, we are updating our outlook for energy loan losses. 
As noted previously, these various methodologies led us to an estimated energy loan -- energy loan losses of between $75 million to $125 million for the 9-quarter period ending the fourth quarter of 2016. That was estimated more than a year ago based upon oil prices near $50. It is obviously considerably -- the price of oil was obviously considerably lower than that today, with most of that decline occurring during December 2015 and January 2016. So it's appropriate to provide an update about loss expectation. 
Assuming $30 per barrel for the next several quarters, we estimate that energy loan losses will be between $75 million and $100 million in 2016. This is on the high end of the initial range but has been driven by the decline in the oil and gas prices relative to the initial expectation. And as Paul just mentioned, we expect total losses for the company to remain manageable, with net charge-offs ranging between 30 and 35 basis points for the entire consolidated portfolio. We continue to build our energy loan loss reserve to a level above 5%. This is a strong reserve, particularly relative to various measures loss expectations that we've reported in the past and have been reported by peers.
On Slide 17, we are providing some additional disclosures on trends in various major types of energy credits, with the orange line representing upstream or exploration and production loans; the green line representing energy services; and the yellow line representing all other energy-related loans. 
On the left is the trend in balances outstanding. Despite the capital markets being somewhat quiet in the fourth quarter, we still experienced a substantial decline in balances as borrowers continued to sell assets and used cash flow to reduce debt. On the right -- on the top right is the trend in classified energy loans by subtype, with services increasing during fourth quarter, while classified E&P companies experienced a decline in that quarter. Nonaccruals are shown at the bottom. We expect continued downgrades but we expect that the situation, as noted before, will be manageable. 
On Slide 18, we show an updated view of our exposure to commercial real estate in Texas. The darker left-hand side of each bar represents the Houston exposure. The point of this slide really is the Houston CRE portfolio is diversified across a variety of asset types product categories, and we are not concentrated in any one particular area, with a very minimal exposure to land.
Slide 19 is [indiscernible  for us, which shows the commercial real estate portfolio by cash flow and collateral support. You'll notice that there's very low in the way of tail risk. Property values could decline or cash flow could decline substantially, and very few properties would run into substantial trouble. 
While I'm happy to talk about our exposure to specific product types, there are some keys to our commercial real estate exposure which are worth mentioning. When comparing our Texas exposure today to the 2008 downturn, there are several important factors that position us much more conservatively today. They include: first, that our total commercial real estate balances are approximately $1.2 billion less today than they were going into 2008; and exposure to land is down more than 80% from what we saw going into the previous cycle. 
Additionally, our mix of construction lending and CRE term lending has shifted much more to CRE term. Generally speaking, the amount of equity required in office and multifamily construction financing is almost double today what it was going into the previous cycle of 2008. With that as a bit of a backdrop, Paul, I'll turn the call back over to you.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Scott. Slide 20 depicts our outlook for the next 12 months relative to the most recent quarter. We are maintaining our slightly to moderately increasing outlook for loans, due primarily to factors already discussed earlier in our comments.Over t
componenttext:
Thanks, Scott. Slide 20 depicts our outlook for the next 12 months relative to the most recent quarter. We are maintaining our slightly to moderately increasing outlook for loans, due primarily to factors already discussed earlier in our comments.
Over the next 4 quarters, we expect net interest income to increase from the fourth quarter levels. We anticipate continued loan and security growth and additional benefit from December's slight rate increase, which will outpace the headwinds of 1 fewer day of interest income and no anticipated large interest income recoveries. 
Our outlook does not include the effect of any future rate increases by the Federal Reserve, although we expect a benefit to annual net interest income of about $100 million for every 100 basis point increase in short-term rates. We expect our quarterly provision that is moderately higher than the fourth quarter of 2015, assuming energy prices remain near current levels. We expect to maintain a strong reserve ratio on energy loans. 
We expect the noninterest income, excluding dividends and securities gains and losses, will increase slightly to moderately as we continue to focus heavily on these line items. As a reminder, dividend from federal agencies, namely the Federal Home Loan Bank, will decline due to the charter consolidation. You may recall we had multiple memberships to several federal home loan banks, and we're consolidating those to a single federal home loan bank. And due to the Fast Act, which is more commonly known as the Highway Spending Bill and its impact on dividends from the Federal Reserve. 
Noninterest expense, as stated previously, we are committed to holding noninterest expenses to less than $1.6 billion for 2016, excluding severance and restructuring costs. The effective tax rate for the quarter was about 4 basis points lower than our typical effective tax rate. This is due primarily to investment tax credits realized this quarter related to alternative energy and research and development. We expect our effective tax rate to be closer to 34% in 2016, which may fluctuate somewhat due to how much of our investment in technology projects is eligible for tax credits. 
We expect preferred dividends to continue to decline. The tender offer completed in the fourth quarter reduces preferred dividends by approximately $10 million annually, although the amounts are uneven. For example, assuming no changes to the outstanding preferred equity from today, the first and third quarter dividend rates are expected to be 112 [ph] -- or I'm sorry, $12 million each, and the second and fourth quarters should be approximately $15 million each.
This concludes our prepared remarks. So would you please open the line for questions? Thank you.

componenttext: I would tell you that I would certainly expect so. We have not developed the capital plan that will accompany our submission of our stress test and through the CCAR process, which is just getting underway. But we would expect to be more aggressive than we've been certainly in the last cycle in terms of what we hope to accomplish in the way of capital returns. And that -- I expect that will be on the table, Jennifer. But that's [indiscernible] determine in consultation with the management team here and then to go through the CCAR process. But that's what I would sort of expect we will be doing.

componenttext: Well Jennifer, I think that's something that we typically disclose. As Scott said, however, we do believe we have a healthy reserve at over 5% of outstanding loans.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Scott, maybe a little more color on the paydowns that you did see in the energy book during the quarter. Just kind of what the nature of those were. Are you starting to see any evidence of money or other energy companies buying out others, just kind of ge
componenttext: Scott, maybe a little more color on the paydowns that you did see in the energy book during the quarter. Just kind of what the nature of those were. Are you starting to see any evidence of money or other energy companies buying out others, just kind of get a sense of kind of where the paydowns could go and where you're kind of -- those are stemming from.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Brad. No, good question. Actually, the paydowns are coming much more -- they're more heavily weighted to the services portfolio, number one. Number two, we -- you're going to see a natural contraction in the reserve base outstandings as those -- as
componenttext: Sure, Brad. No, good question. Actually, the paydowns are coming much more -- they're more heavily weighted to the services portfolio, number one. Number two, we -- you're going to see a natural contraction in the reserve base outstandings as those -- as the redetermination came down during the quarter, the borrowing bases were redetermined down. We saw some natural payouts there. And those would be the 2 primary areas. And we saw continued term amortization. Recall that on the services side of our portfolio, about 35% of the portfolio was term advertising on a little less than a 5-year basis. And so we're continuing to see reductions there. And then the last comment I would make is that during the year, we had approximately $140 million of capital contributed by private equity firms, and that didn't all go to support reductions. But it -- a portion of it did. And additionally, we saw about $150 million in loan commitments reduced as a result of restructurings that we did. So really, it's across the board, and it's all pretty healthy type reduction that you wouldn't anticipate.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016

componenttext: Yes. The current price deck is in the low $30s, and then obviously, it goes up from there. But the current low end is about $32. Our sensitivity case for 2016 drops down to $24. So that's -- we've had about 11 [ph] price deck reductions over the last, I'd say, 12 to 18 months. And you'd see the same sort of conservative nature on the natural gas pricing as well.

componenttextpreview: Okay. Yes. I think we've been pretty consistent in saying that over the course of 2 to 3 years, we would be investing approximately $6 billion of cash in the investment portfolio and the timing of that may change. So I wouldn't say that it was any particu
componenttext: Okay. Yes. I think we've been pretty consistent in saying that over the course of 2 to 3 years, we would be investing approximately $6 billion of cash in the investment portfolio and the timing of that may change. So I wouldn't say that it was any particular view on the yield curve, but we are trying to be somewhat thoughtful about the timing of those investments. But look, looking forward, I would expect to continue kind of in the range of the pace of the purchases that we have been making.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That helps. And then just as the follow-up, on Page 16 in terms of the energy loss expectations of $75 million to $100 million over the next 4 quarters. I know we've been in the energy crisis, I guess, for some time. But just in terms of the path of
componenttext: Okay. That helps. And then just as the follow-up, on Page 16 in terms of the energy loss expectations of $75 million to $100 million over the next 4 quarters. I know we've been in the energy crisis, I guess, for some time. But just in terms of the path of losses, right? Are we talking about the loss over the next 4 quarters. But with oil at $30 today, are we more likely when we look into 2017 -- obviously, we have the reserve builds now, but are we more likely to see even higher losses in 2017? I'm just trying to understand the default path of energy companies.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ken, it's obviously very difficult to estimate what 2017 would look like. The price decline in the last month has been -- last 30 days has been very similar to last year in terms of kind of magnitude and we're obviously in a different level. And so we --
componenttext: Ken, it's obviously very difficult to estimate what 2017 would look like. The price decline in the last month has been -- last 30 days has been very similar to last year in terms of kind of magnitude and we're obviously in a different level. And so we -- all of that pushed us to say that we would be at the upper end of the range that we originally stated for 2016. And I think what you'll look for us -- what you'll look for us to do is mid-year, we'll have a better sense of how long this is going to last and what portion of '17. But if -- to answer your question very specifically, if prices did stay in this current level through 2017, you'd probably see losses in '17 of about the same magnitude than we're suggesting for 2016.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Marty Mosby of Vining Sparks.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Marty Mosby of Vining Sparks.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask you just about -- as you look at the discount that's kind of evolved into your stock price, I would you would calculate the earnings power of the cushion for potential losses. Now I just want to make sure I got this right. If we look at th
componenttext: I wanted to ask you just about -- as you look at the discount that's kind of evolved into your stock price, I would you would calculate the earnings power of the cushion for potential losses. Now I just want to make sure I got this right. If we look at the pretax on our earnings cushion, you had about $125 million per quarter. And that would relate to about what you have right now in energy reserves, which represents 5% of the portfolio. So if you look at each quarter, you're generating in excess of another 5% before you would ever get into a capital, so be kind of hit to the capital position versus just reducing earnings. So just wanted you to kind of talk a little bit about earnings cushion and potential losses in energy.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: You've done a very nice job. I think we start with first -- we start with a very strong capital and strong reserves not only for energy but across the portfolio. And the rest of the portfolio continues to improve. I mean, it's -- energy is the only place
componenttext: You've done a very nice job. I think we start with first -- we start with a very strong capital and strong reserves not only for energy but across the portfolio. And the rest of the portfolio continues to improve. I mean, it's -- energy is the only place we're seeing stress. So I think we feel like the risk of any real capital need, any external source of capital are going to be very is not on the horizon of anything we expect to happen at the present time.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the guidance we gave on 30 to 35 basis points of net charge-offs is again very manageable in the sense of our overall capital generation. And that assumes a pretty pejorative outlook for the energy sector. So you do have to -- once you move away fro
componenttext: Well, the guidance we gave on 30 to 35 basis points of net charge-offs is again very manageable in the sense of our overall capital generation. And that assumes a pretty pejorative outlook for the energy sector. So you do have to -- once you move away from your analysis of energy, you have to look at how energy sits inside our total financial structure. And as you noted and Harris noted, it's -- there's a lot of balance there.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: There's a lot of incremental capital being generated each quarter just with the earnings power you have now. And then Paul, the other thing I was just trying to really look at is before the stock price got into a discount such a discount than it is now, I
componenttext: There's a lot of incremental capital being generated each quarter just with the earnings power you have now. And then Paul, the other thing I was just trying to really look at is before the stock price got into a discount such a discount than it is now, I thought dividends would be kind of the focus. But once you get this bigger gap, share repurchase becomes so valuable, hence, the change in stock price change the way you would just asking about the level that but maybe your priority. Would share repurchase be a bigger priority now where the stock price is relative to maybe year-end?

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Again, it could well be -- I mean, that's a conversation we have yet to have with our board, but I think we clearly recognize the power of repurchases right now.
componenttext: Again, it could well be -- I mean, that's a conversation we have yet to have with our board, but I think we clearly recognize the power of repurchases right now.

componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Paul Miller of FBR.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: There was an OCC letter about CRE exposure and worry, I think you guys a little bit worried about some banks taking exposure there with concerned. Can you talk a little bit about how you're dealing with that OCC letter, and is it a big concern there at Zi
componenttext: There was an OCC letter about CRE exposure and worry, I think you guys a little bit worried about some banks taking exposure there with concerned. Can you talk a little bit about how you're dealing with that OCC letter, and is it a big concern there at Zions?

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016

componenttext: We'll have Michael Morris, our Chief to speak to that. Michael?

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, the OCC letter focused a lot on multifamily and a lot on the buildup in community banks, especially in multifamily. And we feel very comfortable with our multifamily exposure in all of the markets that we're in, that we have in place, with the
componenttext: Sure. Well, the OCC letter focused a lot on multifamily and a lot on the buildup in community banks, especially in multifamily. And we feel very comfortable with our multifamily exposure in all of the markets that we're in, that we have in place, with the equity sponsors we bank. Our average loan-to-cost in the construction side is around 60%, 65%. So that translates into something less than that in LTV. So 55%, 60% LTV on projects that are still continuing to lease up and stabilize at rents that were either pro forma or in excess of pro forma. So where we see the pressure coming will be on cap rates as overall yields move up if they do, might not be the favored asset class than it has been so that could put some pressure on cap rates, which will increase the loan-to-value. But I will watch it carefully and we feel good about our exposure.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And do you think where your level of exposure in that area would have to decline or could stay where it is?
componenttext: And do you think where your level of exposure in that area would have to decline or could stay where it is?

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: We think it can stay where it is and go right into a cycle where there might be a little bit of softness in rent growth and cap rate increase, but we're comfortable where it is. We don't actually want it to pay off and go out into the capital markets rath
componenttext: We think it can stay where it is and go right into a cycle where there might be a little bit of softness in rent growth and cap rate increase, but we're comfortable where it is. We don't actually want it to pay off and go out into the capital markets rather than to the agency side.

componenttext: My first question is a follow-up to Ken's. Paul, you noted that the rate of future securities purchases would be similar to what we've seen in the past. But I'm calculating 1.5% [ph] on average for this quarter as you mentioned and then 6 10 [ph] in the previous quarter. Given that this is such a powerful NII driver for you it seems, I just want to get it right. What should we assume for about the level set of purchases per quarter?

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016

componenttext: Erika, sorry if I misspoke. What I meant to say is our purchases going forward would be in the range of what you experience so you kind of outlined the range of possibilities. But I would expect to continue to make purchases in that range for the -- at least for the next 4 quarters. And then hopefully, they would be sort of somewhat reflective of the opportunity that the market gives us. But we are clearly understand the earnings power of those security additions that are focused on continuing to deliver that. I should also say that those portfolio additions, as I said in my slide comments, we are paying special attention to the duration of the bonds we're putting on and the extension risk, either typically agency ARMs and the agency 10-year final maturity pass-throughs, which again have, we believe, more predictable characteristics as it relates to the extension risk on those additions.

componenttext: Right, Erika. We are particularly mindful of the LCR and the securities that we're putting on. We are adding in the context of HQLA so either Level 1 or Level 2 in the appropriate proportions. I don't believe we disclosed our LCR but I will say that we are comfortably in excess of the requirement.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, I guess, the short answer is until we see the nonenergy economies start to really fray. But we're not seeing that. We -- and I don't think we're going to venture guess as to run the cycle really starts to turn, et cetera but once you do that
componenttext: Well, I mean, I guess, the short answer is until we see the nonenergy economies start to really fray. But we're not seeing that. We -- and I don't think we're going to venture guess as to run the cycle really starts to turn, et cetera but once you do that. I think suffice to say that at the moment, we continue to see improvement. And even in markets like -- in a market like Texas, the nonenergy portfolio remains very healthy. We are looking at a lot of indicators in each of those portfolios to kind of -- watching for problems. And so far, it is not really showing up. So anything, Michael you want to add to that?

componenttext: Direct to maybe the appendix Slide 25, and this might be helpful for you as you look at -- we haven't broken out a lot of information on past loan migration in the past, but this is a little bit of a FICO score analysis of what's happening both in what we term rest of the high oil and gas employment counties. And that's the same story that you'd see if you looked at our small business portfolio and middle-market portfolios.

componenttext: The -- well, the point I was making there, this is Paul, are on the outlook for noninterest income the sources of dividends in the past are not going to be there going forward. And Federal Home Loan Bank stock, it's kind of in the $5 million to $7 million range. So you're looking at in the aggregate about $10 million of reduced dividends from those sources in '16 versus '15.

componenttext: Given that some of the securities buying that you've done over the last couple of quarters and your expectations over the next several quarters, where do you see your asset sensitivity on 100 and 200 basis point move once you fully complete some of the balance sheet restructuring over the next give it a year or 2?

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Paul. My expectation is that given our starting point, which was, as you know, we screened very high on asset sensitivity. Even after taking into consideration the fixed-rate asset purchases that we contemplate here over the next year or so, my ex
componenttext: This is Paul. My expectation is that given our starting point, which was, as you know, we screened very high on asset sensitivity. Even after taking into consideration the fixed-rate asset purchases that we contemplate here over the next year or so, my expectation is that while our asset sensitivity will be reduced, we will have converted all of that sort of potential income into actual income. And we will still screen, in my opinion, on the high end of asset sensitivity relative to our peers.

componenttext: We haven't quantified that. Maybe and I can work together and figure out what might make sense. But I think that if you look at the spread of asset sensitivity around the peers and I said we're still going to be at the high end of that.

componenttext: We actually have 4 models that we're utilizing at the moment. In the -- and they cover the full gamut from $20 a barrel up to higher levels. componenttext: I appreciate the question but we're -- it's really is a moving target. We're not going to sort of disclose each one of our scenarios and -- but suffice it to say that we have evaluated it at that level from multiple different approaches, and we believe that the again what we forecasted would be well in the range of lower prices.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I think the question is if they're going to be a complete cliff in that process.
componenttext: And I think the question is if they're going to be a complete cliff in that process.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: There's generally not a complete cliff. I mean, the nice thing about the reserve-based lending is that it is unlike any other type of commercial lending we do, it is made to adjust on a periodic basis. And it works far better than working capital revolver
componenttext: There's generally not a complete cliff. I mean, the nice thing about the reserve-based lending is that it is unlike any other type of commercial lending we do, it is made to adjust on a periodic basis. And it works far better than working capital revolvers, receivables and inventory. And the industry, E&P companies, they know how to live within their cash flow generally speaking problem so won't encounter problems, but they know how to ratchet back cash flow. And it fundamentally comes in the form of controlling their CapEx. But they have many other things to control, including the cost that they receive from services companies, which are down anywhere from 25% to 35% in 2016. The other thing that you probably read about is that just lifting cost. Pure cash lifting costs, depending on the company, depending on the reservoir, et cetera, et cetera, are generally in the $7 to $12 range, pure cash lifting cost. So there's a lot of data points in what I just described to you, but because of these revolvers -- the borrowing bases are redetermined every 6 months through comprehensive engineering, we -- they adjust very naturally. So you rarely run in to a peer brickwall.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. My follow-up is on the commercial real estate portfolio. On a linked-quarter basis, the term CRE book was up 4.5%. The first time in a while you've put up that type of growth in that book. Is that something that's sticky and could you see a continue
componenttext: Okay. My follow-up is on the commercial real estate portfolio. On a linked-quarter basis, the term CRE book was up 4.5%. The first time in a while you've put up that type of growth in that book. Is that something that's sticky and could you see a continued growth at that pace? Or I was just wondering what's changed that you feel comfortable crowing that.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Michael. I would say that without really digging into the number, that a lot of that growth came from conversion from construction to term. And when that happens, it's a lot easier for that to stick to the books and a lot easier for us to write te
componenttext: This is Michael. I would say that without really digging into the number, that a lot of that growth came from conversion from construction to term. And when that happens, it's a lot easier for that to stick to the books and a lot easier for us to write terms of than it is originate fresh near-term loans that may not have the kind of risk profile that we want. So we have really put the decelerator on C&D, especially in the multifamily side. So a lot of that will be conversion to term. But some of the business units are originating the terms so that we can continue to create a more stabilized CRE portfolio with stabilized income streams.

componenttext: Sure. The -- let me just sort of give you a broad sense of this. componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Zions Bancorporation's Fourth Quarter 2015 Earning Results Webcast Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this call is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to James Abbott, Director of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good evening. We welcome you to this conference call to discuss our fourth quarter 2015 earnings. Our primary participants today will be Harris Simmons, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; Scott McLean, President and Chief Operating Offic
componenttext:
Thank you, and good evening. We welcome you to this conference call to discuss our fourth quarter 2015 earnings. Our primary participants today will be Harris Simmons, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; Scott McLean, President and Chief Operating Officer; and Paul Burdiss, Chief Financial Officer.
I would like to remind you that during this call, we will be making forward-looking statements although actual results may differ materially. We encourage you to review the disclaimer in this press release dealing with forward-looking information, which applies equally to statements made in this call.
A full copy of the earnings release will be -- as well as the supplemental slide deck are available at zionsbancorporation.com. We will be referring to the slides during this call. We intend to limit the length of this call to 1 hour, which will include a question-and-answer section. [Operator Instructions] I will now turn the time over to Harris Simmons.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, James, and welcome to all of you who are on the call today to discuss our fourth quarter and full year 2015 results.There's obviously a lot of focus on energy, and we'll talk about energy as we get further into the presentation. But I want to
componenttext:
Thank you, James, and welcome to all of you who are on the call today to discuss our fourth quarter and full year 2015 results.
There's obviously a lot of focus on energy, and we'll talk about energy as we get further into the presentation. But I want to talk about a variety of things that we think are actually working very nicely before we get to that.
On Slide 3 in the related slides that we distributed, we've tried to highlight some of the initiatives that are working well or within our expectations. I'll touch on a few of these in my remarks here, but as an overarching comment, I would want to say that I am quite encouraged with the positive operating leverage that we achieved in the quarter, the positive revenue trajectory, the stable expense levels and the solid progress that we've made on the technology project that we're pursuing.
We are highly focused on improving the profitability and growth profile of the company, and we made very tangible progress in 2015 towards those goals. Additionally, despite the weakness in energy commodity prices, we are able to maintain strong overall asset quality metrics, and we experienced an encouraging improvement in the rate of loan growth compared to the prior quarter during the fourth quarter here.
On Slide 4, we display our loans and deposits. Relative to the third quarter, we experienced improved loan growth in the fourth quarter at $536 million or about 5% annualized. Excluding the effects of expected energy loan attrition, loan growth was more than $700 million or about 8% annualized.
We were pleased with growth in areas that are targeted for growth, specifically non-energy commercial and industrial and consumer loans. Deposit growth shown in the chart on the right has been a strong story for Zions for quite some time, and the source of that growth has come primarily from the most viable source, which is noninterest-bearing deposits. The value of those deposits should increase as rates rise and should lead to a strong increase in earnings if and when interest rates further increase. Thus far, we've been able to hold deposit rates quite flat.
Turning to Slide 5. The most significant source of revenue for Zions is net interest income, which equals about 78% of the fourth quarter net revenue. Although a portion of the increase from the prior quarter was driven by interest income recoveries that may not occur in the first quarter of 2016, we expect the interest rate increase in December will offset that factor. Also driving net interest income higher was the increase in both loans and securities as well as the material reduction in interest paid on debt. Accordingly, we expect we'll experience similar, if not slightly higher, net interest income in the first quarter of 2016.
On Slide 6, we were encouraged with the results from the initiatives we've made to grow fee income. Managed fee income increased 4% from the 2014 year, and we are targeting a stronger growth rate in 2016. Managed fee income is defined by us as income sources we manage directly and excludes the effect of dividends, security gains and losses and other similar sources.
The most significant increase in 2015 was from treasury management, which increased 13%. It also happens to be our strongest contributor to total fee income. Some of the headwinds include loan fees, which were down due in part to soft demand for energy lending as well as overdraft fees, which is attributable at least in part to strengthening consumer balance sheets.
On Slide 7, we have the cost savings initiative scorecard graph, with the bar on the left illustrating the commitment to achieve $120 million of gross cost savings by the end of 2017, the bar on the right illustrating the cost saves that were accomplished in 2015. We remain on track to achieve the targeted cost reductions by 2017, having already realized more than half of the goal by the end of 2015.
We're encouraged with the achievement of holding noninterest expense to less than $1.6 billion in 2015. Additionally, our commitment is to hold that line item, adjusted for certain restructuring costs, to below $1.6 billion in 2016. We expect benefits in 2016 to include the simplification of operations that are due in part to the charter consolidation.
Moving to Slide 8. We have achieved a portion of another key measure of our commitment to shareholders, which was to reduce the efficiency ratio to 70% or below in the second half of 2015. We're encouraged with this achievement, and we are reiterating our commitment to achieve an efficiency ratio in 2016 of 66% or better as well as those other targets that we first communicated on June 1 of last year.
On Slide 9, we are satisfied with the progress we have made on our technology projects. The general ledger transition and new reporting tool conversion are complete. The credit approval workflow system software is installed in most of our banks, with the completion scheduled for the spring of this year. The same is true for the enterprise loan operations. We're tracking for a spring completion.
Regarding our core systems replacement project, which we've dubbed FutureCore and where we've partnered with Tata Consultancy Services, we're expecting the consumer loan system to roll out later this year, with commercial lending tracking for 2017 and the deposits module scheduled for 2018. In summary, we are making significant investments to provide a very strong technology foundation for our future. These are investments that will simplify our operating environment and give us the ability to be highly competitive in an industry where technology is obviously playing an increasingly important role.
Finally, as noted in the press release, the consolidation of our 7 subsidiary banks to a single national bank charter was completed on December 31. We'll continue to emphasize our locally oriented leadership structure and the power of our strong local brand in each market we serve. But we'll find some additional efficiency from this consolidation of charters. We're very optimistic about the future operational and financial performance for Zions.
With that brief overview, I'll turn the call over to Paul Burdiss to review the financial results. Paul?

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Harris, and good afternoon, everyone. I'll begin on Slide 10. For the fourth quarter of 2015, Zions reported net earnings to common shareholders of $88 million or $0.43 per share. Relative to the third quarter, net interest income increased abo
componenttext:
Thank you, Harris, and good afternoon, everyone. I'll begin on Slide 10. For the fourth quarter of 2015, Zions reported net earnings to common shareholders of $88 million or $0.43 per share. Relative to the third quarter, net interest income increased about 5.5%.
Adjusted for recoveries of interest income and a linked-quarter increase in income from loans purchased from the FDIC, net interest income increased just under 3%. Actively managed noninterest income, which excludes investment-related items like security gains and losses, increased slightly from the prior quarter, and as Harris mentioned earlier, increased about 4% for the full year 2015 when compared to the full year 2014.
At just over $400 million, noninterest expenses were higher in the fourth quarter when compared to the third quarter due in part to elevated levels of expenses in certain categories as detailed in the press release, which accompanied this call. We are encouraged by the efforts of our teammates to manage our cost of doing business. Our collective efforts allow Zions to realize our goal of adjusted noninterest expense at less than $1.6 billion for 2015.
Turning to the provision for loan and lease losses. We had expected a moderate build in the reserve for energy loans partially offset by continued reserve release in the portfolio. Although throughout most of the quarter, we expected the provision for loan losses to be in line with the third quarter results, the decline in the price of oil near the end of the quarter resulted in a moderately higher provision. The energy loan portfolio continued to perform about as we had expected.
As we progress through 2016, we expect quarterly provisions to be moderately higher than the fourth quarter results. The key driver of our expectation for an elevated provision in 2016 is lower prevailing energy prices. Actual results may therefore vary from expectations if energy prices remain volatile.
Finally, I would like to highlight the return on tangible common equity. Although we are working to drive shareholder returns to a much higher level, I'll point out that our efforts over the past year have resulted in a better than 100 basis point increase in shareholder returns when compared to the same period a year ago, while capital levels have actually increased slightly during the period.
Turning to Slide 11. I'll address some of the drivers of net interest income, beginning with volume. Details of our investment portfolio are shown here on Slide 11. We have been adding securities to our investment portfolio for the past year or so, reflecting the need for a permanent high-quality liquid asset position in order to manage our balance sheet liquidity more effectively and in light of the recently established liquidity coverage ratio rules.
Our efforts to build out the investment portfolio are expected to add revenue in the current and downside economic environment when compared to holding liquidity in the form of cash. During the fourth quarter, we added $1.5 billion to our investment securities portfolio on average when compared to the third quarter. In light of the general market expectation for rising short-term rates, we are exercising caution with respect to the impact on overall balance sheet interest rate sensitivity as we purchase fixed-rate investments and duration extension risk inherent in the investment portfolio.
The securities we are adding are relatively short in duration, just over 3 years. The duration of the entire securities portfolio is estimated to be 2.9 years today. If rates were to rise 200 basis points across the curve, our models indicate that the duration of the portfolio would extend only slightly to about 3.1 years. As expected, the addition of these fixed-rate investments reduced Zions' asset sensitivity somewhat as shown in the table at the bottom right of the page.
Worth noting, the deposit beta assumptions employed in our "Slowed" case are, in fact, faster than what we are seeing in the market today, or in plain language, our "Slow" scenario model assumes faster deposit repricing than we are currently observing in the market. So the improvement in net interest income from the December rate hike could and likely will be higher than that shown in the table on Slide 11.
On Page 12, we break down year-over-year loan growth. Overall, we are encouraged with our fourth quarter loan growth despite some headwinds, as Harris mentioned earlier. Compared to the prior quarter, period-end loans grew at a little over 5% annualized. Net commercial and industrial loan growth for the last year was about 6% when excluding the effect of energy loan attrition. It is important to note that we have accomplished this growth without an adverse change in our underwriting standards.
Year-over-year, net churn in commercial real estate growth was about 8% when removing the effect of national real estate portfolio. Residential mortgage continues to be a major focus for growth across our geographic footprint. The other category experienced healthy growth from various subcategories such as home equity and municipal lending.
The 2 portfolios that have been in decline for the past year or more are the national real estate portfolio and the energy portfolio. The national real estate portfolio represents about 6% of loans, and the attrition here resulted in a drag of just over 1 percentage point to the overall growth of the loan portfolio during the past year. The rate of decline is slowing for this portfolio, and it currently accounts for less than 50% of tangible common equity.
The energy portfolio attrition is well documented as we have discussed this regularly during the past year, and our outlook remains consistent. We expect continued attrition as our clients actively work through the current environment for energy prices. To summarize, our outlook on loan growth for the next 12 months is for a slightly to moderately increasing portfolio, which should be in the low to mid-single-digit rate of growth range.
Another key component of net interest income, which is the yield or rates on the portfolio and loan production can be found on Slide 13. This slide breaks down key components of our net interest margin. The top line is the loan yield, which increased 6 basis points from the second quarter to average 4.24%. As described in the press release, there was a recovery of interest income of about $8 million included in the fourth quarter loan yield. Excluding this recovery, the loan yield on the portfolio declined about 2 basis points from the prior quarter.
The securities portfolio yield declined slightly this quarter, largely due to the changing composition of the portfolio as we add new bonds within our guidelines for duration and extension risk. At the bottom of the chart is a line depicting our cost of funds as a percent of earning assets, which continues to be quite low and declined slightly from the prior quarter due to the redemption of high-cost subordinated debt. The net interest margin increased to 3.23%, a 12 basis point increase from the third quarter.
If adjusted for the income recovery, the net interest margin would have been about 3.18%. This increase is largely attributable to the change in earning asset mix, more loans and securities in the fourth quarter and less cash as well as the previously mentioned reduction of high-cost subordinated debt.
Slide 14 provides more detail on loan yields, specifically the coupon on new loan production versus the total portfolio, which we believe is helpful in understanding the risk to the future yield on loans in the current interest rate environment. The yellow line reflects the GAAP yield on the portfolio. The primary reason for this increase is the previously mentioned interest recoveries.
Importantly, the weighted average coupon of loan portfolio has been stable over the past couple of quarters. The coupon, of course, excludes the effect of amortizing fees, discounts and premiums. The yield on new production also stabilized in the fourth quarter as we saw the yield on larger loans improved somewhat in December, reflective of the move in LIBOR. Although our loan officers are seeing some pricing pressure in the small loan space, our production coupons have been stable.
Turning to credit quality on Slide 15. I'll be brief and say that we continue to experience generally strong credit quality performance in most geographies and segments, with the notable exception of energy-related loans, which are included in our C&I segment. Our reserve for credit loss is quite strong at just under 1.7% of loans, which is nearly 2x our nonperforming assets and over a decade worth of charge-offs based on the fourth quarter annualized results. Despite an increase in classified energy-related loans of just under -- I'm sorry, just over $76 million from the prior quarter level, overall classified loans increased only $45 million or 3% in the fourth quarter.
Nonperforming assets declined slightly from the prior quarter. Net charge-offs declined due to recoveries, which were $32 million for the fourth quarter of 2015. Gross charge-offs were relatively stable when compared to the prior quarter. Our outlook for 2016 net charge-offs is between 30 and 35 basis points of average loans. The majority of these charge-offs are expected to be energy-related.
With that, I'll turn the call over to Scott to discuss energy lending and the Houston market more broadly.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Paul, and I'll start on Slide 17. We've not repeated the table that we have in our earnings release on Page 4 of the earnings release in this -- in the main section of this slide deck, although it can be found in the appendix. But let me just m
componenttext:
Thank you, Paul, and I'll start on Slide 17. We've not repeated the table that we have in our earnings release on Page 4 of the earnings release in this -- in the main section of this slide deck, although it can be found in the appendix. But let me just make some summary comments.
As noted in the press release, energy loan outstandings and commitments declined fairly substantially from the prior quarter and from a year ago. We commented that we believe this would happen throughout 2015. The decline in outstandings was about $450 million compared to a year ago, and commitments are down approximately $1 billion since a year ago.
Classified energy loan balances increased by approximately $76 million from the prior quarter and finished at a level that is actually somewhat better than what we would have expected a year ago. Nonaccrual energy loans declined from the prior quarter, primarily due to net charge-offs, which is not the way you want to reduce that bucket. But it's important to note that the level did not increase much if you adjust for net charge-offs.
Turning to Slide 16 -- let's see. It's not Slide 16. It's probably Slide 17, yes. Or is it -- sorry, yes. As we noted since late 2014, we have been extremely active in managing the energy portfolio, including the full attention of our entire executive team, reviewing the portfolio frequently on a credit-by-credit basis plus significant interaction with our customers. Based upon that input, along with our models, we are updating our outlook for energy loan losses.
As noted previously, these various methodologies led us to an estimated energy loan -- energy loan losses of between $75 million to $125 million for the 9-quarter period ending the fourth quarter of 2016. That was estimated more than a year ago based upon oil prices near $50. It is obviously considerably -- the price of oil was obviously considerably lower than that today, with most of that decline occurring during December 2015 and January 2016. So it's appropriate to provide an update to that loss expectation.
Assuming $30 per barrel for the next several quarters, we estimate that energy loan losses will be between $75 million and $100 million in 2016. This is on the high end of the initial range but has been driven by the decline in the oil and gas prices relative to the initial expectation. And as Paul just mentioned, we expect total losses for the company to remain manageable, with net charge-offs ranging between 30 and 35 basis points for the entire consolidated portfolio. We continue to build our energy loan loss reserve to a level above 5%. This is a strong reserve, particularly relative to various measures of problem loans and loss expectations that we've reported in the past and that have been reported by peers.
On Slide 17, we are providing some additional disclosures on trends in the various major types of energy credits, with the orange line representing upstream or exploration and production loans; the green line representing energy services; and the yellow line representing all other energy-related loans.
On the left is the trend in balances outstanding. Despite the capital markets being somewhat quiet in the fourth quarter, we still experienced a substantial decline in balances as borrowers continue to sell assets and use cash flow to reduce debt. On the right -- on the top right is the trend in classified energy loans by subtype, with services increasing during the fourth quarter, while classified E&P companies experienced a decline in that quarter. Nonaccruals are shown at the bottom. We expect continued downgrades but we expect that the situation, as noted before, will be manageable.
On Slide 18, we show an updated view of our exposure to commercial real estate in Texas. The darker left-hand side of each bar represents the Houston exposure. The point of this slide really is that the Houston CRE portfolio is diversified across a variety of asset types, product categories, and we are not concentrated in any one particular area, with very minimal exposure to land.
Slide 19 is a new disclosure for us, which shows the commercial real estate portfolio by cash flow and collateral support. You'll notice that there's very little in the way of tail risk. Property values could decline or cash flow could decline substantially, and very few properties would run into substantial trouble.
While I'm happy to talk about our exposure to specific product types, there are some keys to our commercial real estate exposure which are worth mentioning. When comparing our Texas exposure today to the 2008 downturn, there are several important factors that position us much more conservatively today. They include, first, that our total commercial real estate balances are approximately $1.2 billion less today than they were going into 2008; and our exposure to land is down more than 80% from what we saw going into the previous cycle.
Additionally, our mix of construction lending and CRE term lending has shifted much more to CRE term. Generally speaking, the amount of equity required in office and multifamily construction financing is almost double today what it was going into the previous cycle of 2008. With that as a bit of a backdrop, Paul, I'll turn the call back over to you.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Scott. Slide 20 depicts our outlook for the next 12 months relative to the most recent quarter. We are maintaining our slightly to moderately increasing outlook for loans due primarily to factors already discussed earlier in our comments.Over th
componenttext:
Thanks, Scott. Slide 20 depicts our outlook for the next 12 months relative to the most recent quarter. We are maintaining our slightly to moderately increasing outlook for loans due primarily to factors already discussed earlier in our comments.
Over the next 4 quarters, we expect net interest income to increase from the fourth quarter level. We anticipate continued loan and security growth and additional benefit from December's slight rate increase, which will outpace the headwinds of 1 fewer day of interest income and no anticipated large interest income recoveries.
Our outlook does not include the effect of any future rate increases by the Federal Reserve, although we expect a benefit to annual net interest income of about $100 million for every 100 basis point increase in short-term rates. We expect a quarterly provision that is moderately higher than the fourth quarter of 2015, assuming energy prices remain near current levels. We expect to maintain a strong reserve ratio on energy loans.
We expect the noninterest income, excluding dividends and securities gains and losses, will increase slightly to moderately as we continue to focus heavily on these line items. As a reminder, dividend from federal agencies, namely the Federal Home Loan Banks, will decline due to the charter consolidation. You may recall we had multiple memberships to several Federal Home Loan Banks, and we're consolidating those to a single Federal Home Loan Bank. And due to the FAST Act, which is more commonly known as the highway spending bill and its impact on dividends from the Federal Reserve.
Noninterest expense, as stated previously, we are committed to holding noninterest expense to less than $1.6 billion for 2016, excluding severance and restructuring costs. The effective tax rate for the quarter was about 4 basis points lower than our typical effective tax rate. This is due primarily to investment tax credits realized this quarter related to alternative energy and research and development. We expect our effective tax rate to be closer to 34% in 2016, which may fluctuate somewhat due to how much of our investment in technology projects is eligible for tax credits.
We expect preferred dividends to continue to decline. The tender offer completed in the fourth quarter reduces preferred dividends by approximately $10 million annually, although the amounts are uneven. For example, assuming no changes to the outstanding preferred equity from today, the first and third quarter dividend rates are expected to be 112 -- or I'm sorry, $12 million each, and the second and fourth quarters should be approximately $15 million each.
This concludes our prepared remarks. Sabrina, would you please open the line for questions? Thank you.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016

componenttext: Could you guys -- you still have a healthy capital ratio. Just wondered if you have any interest in share repurchases once we get that -- once we get through CCAR, given your stock is taking quite a hit in the last several weeks.

componenttextpreview: I would tell you that I would certainly expect so. We have not developed the capital plan that will accompany our submission of our stress test and the -- through the CCAR process, which is just getting underway. But we would expect to be more aggressive
componenttext: I would tell you that I would certainly expect so. We have not developed the capital plan that will accompany our submission of our stress test and the -- through the CCAR process, which is just getting underway. But we would expect to be more aggressive than we've been certainly in the last cycle in terms of what we'll hope to accomplish in the way of capital returns. And that -- I expect that will be on the table, Jennifer. But obviously, that's for our board to contemplate and determine in the consultation with the management team here and then to go through the CCAR process. But that's what I would sort of expect we will be doing.

componenttext: Well, Jennifer, I think as you know, that's not something that we typically disclose. As Scott said, however, we do believe we have a healthy reserve at over 5% of outstanding loans.
