componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Zions Bancorporation First Quarter 2016 Earnings Webcast. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call may be recorded. I would now like to turn the conference call over to James Abbott, Director of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Abigail, and good evening. We welcome you to this conference call to discuss our 2016 first quarter earnings. Our primary participants today will be Harris Simmons, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; Scott McLean, President and Chief Operati
componenttext:
Thank you, Abigail, and good evening. We welcome you to this conference call to discuss our 2016 first quarter earnings. Our primary participants today will be Harris Simmons, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; Scott McLean, President and Chief Operating Officer; and Paul Burdiss, Chief Financial Officer. 
I would like to remind you that during this call, we will be making forward-looking statements although actual results may differ materially. We encourage you to review the disclaimer in the press release or the slide deck dealing with forward-looking information, which applies equally to statements made in this call. 
A copy of the full earnings release as well as a supplemental slide deck are available at zionsbancorporation.com. We will be referring to the slides during this call. We intend to limit the length of this call to 1 hour, which will include a question-and-answer section. [Operator Instructions]  
I will now turn the time over to Harris Simmons

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much James, and I want to welcome all of you to our call this afternoon to discuss our first quarter results. I'm going to talk about some information on the accompanying slides, just some opening comments here. On Slide 3, here are some
componenttext:
Thank you very much James, and I want to welcome all of you to our call this afternoon to discuss our first quarter results. I'm going to talk about some information on the accompanying slides, just some opening comments here. 
On Slide 3, here are some highlights for the quarter. We were pleased with the continued strength of strong increases preprovision net revenue, which is the result of solid net interest income growth and adjusted noninterest expense levels that are in line with our stated expense initiatives. 
Another item that appears to be an emerging trend in the last 6 months is stronger loan growth. In the first quarter, loans increased at an annualized rate of 7.6%, accelerating from the prior quarter's rate of 5.3%. It was one of the best first quarter growth rates Zions has posted in the last decade. 
We achieved positive operating leverage for the third consecutive quarter. And we are tracking well on the efficiency initiative that we announced last summer, with the efficiency ratio falling to 68.5%. 
Although there will be much discussion about energy lending on this call, which only comprises about 6% of our loan portfolio, the other 94% of our loan portfolio continues to perform extremely well, and energy is a manageable situation for us. Of note, although that earnings per share only increased $0.01 per share over the prior year period, the change in the provision for credit losses between those 2 quarters is equal to about $0.12 per share. So although energy concerns will be with us for 2016, that effect is fairly transitory compared to the improving trend in underlying financial performance over the course of the last year.
If we turn to Slide 4, our preprovision net revenue has improved by 21% over the past year. This positive [ph] operating leverage has been driven by holding adjusted noninterest expense growth to 2.5%, while adjusted revenue has increased nearly 8% over the same period. We expect to continue to post continued strong momentum in this area over the next couple of years.
On Slide 5, we display our loans and deposits. Relative to the fourth quarter, we experienced an acceleration in the first quarter with loans held for investment increasing, as previously noted, 7.6% annualized after posting a healthy 5.3% annualized growth rate in the prior quarter. We remain pleased with growth in areas that are targeted for growth specifically on energy commercial and industrial and consumer loans. Deposits declined modestly about 1% from the prior quarter, which is somewhat common for a first quarter for us. And the year-over-year improvement of 3.7% is similar to the performance in first quarters over approximately the last decade.
Moving to Slide 6, we are well on our way to achieving another key measure of our commitment to shareholders, which is to reduce the efficiency ratio to 66% or better for the full year 2016. We're encouraged with the improvement from the prior quarter to 68.5% in the first quarter, which included a couple of significant seasonal expense items.
Advancing to Slide 7, including energy loans, credit quality was really solid across the company by various loan types and geographies. Total classified loans increased to 3.7% from 3.4% in the prior quarter and that's -- but aside from energy, classified loans declined slightly to 2% of total loans. Nonperforming assets expressed as a percentage of loans and OREO increased to 1.3% from 0.9% in the prior quarter. However, if one excludes energy credits, nonperforming asset to loan ratio is only 0.7%. 
On the topic of losses, substantially all of the losses in the first quarter were attributable to energy loss. We'll have some further discussion on that later, but the takeaway here is that the energy situation is quite manageable and the overall provision and loss rates remain in line with industry averages.
On Slide 8, this is a repeat of this slide we produced for Investor Day back in February, but it helps to visually show the various initiatives than we are tracking to help improve the operating performance the company. I'm pleased with the progress made in several of these areas in a relatively short period of time, and most initiatives are tracking to the targeted budgets and time lines.
Similarly, Slide 9 is a summary of the key financial performance metrics that we are targeting, and we feel very good about the progress we've made and expect that with continued discipline, that will meet or exceed these goals. 
that overview, I'll turn the call over to Paul Burdiss, our Chief Financial Officer, to review the financial results. Paul?

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Harris.  I'll begin on Slide 10.  For the first quarter of 2016, Zions reported net earnings to common shareholders of $79 million or $0.38 per share.  Relative to the fourth quarter, net interest income increased about $4 million. Adjusted f
componenttext:
Thank you, Harris.  I'll begin on Slide 10.  For the first quarter of 2016, Zions reported net earnings to common shareholders of $79 million or $0.38 per share.  
Relative to the fourth quarter, net interest income increased about $4 million. Adjusted for fourth quarter recoveries of interest income and income from loans purchased from the FDIC, net interest income increased $17 million or about 4% on a linked quarter basis. Customer related fees, which is the bulk of noninterest income, were flat to the fourth quarter and improved about 7% from the first quarter of 2015. 
At just less than $400 million, noninterest expense was slightly lower in the first quarter when compared to the fourth quarter. However, there were several notable items impacting both quarters.  First, on salaries and employee benefits, the first quarter included $6 million related to equity grants to retirement-eligible employees and $7 million in seasonal payroll taxes, while the fourth quarter included an incentive compensation accrual reversal of $5 million. Additionally, as noted on the fourth quarter earnings call, fourth quarter noninterest expenses included elevated levels of FDIC loss sharing expense and an elevated legal accrual. 
We continue to be encouraged by the efforts of our teammates to manage our cost of doing business. Our collective efforts allowed Zions to remain on track toward our goal of adjusted noninterest expenses at less than $1.6 billion for 2016.
Turning to the provision for loan and lease losses, as we conveyed at February's Investor Day, we increased our allowance for credit losses in the first relative to the fourth quarter, reflective of continued stress in our oil and gas portfolio. As we progress through 2016, we currently expect quarterly provisions to be roughly consistent with first quarter results. A key driver of this outlook is overall market conditions, including the level and volatility of energy prices. Scott will provide more detail on our energy portfolio just a moment.
Slide 11 outlines our recent trend in net interest income, which continued to demonstrate strength in the first quarter. On a year-over-year basis, net interest income was about 8.5% -- was up about 8.5% when compared to the first quarter 2015, driven by growth in loans and in the investment portfolio. On a linked quarter basis, net interest income was up on an annualized rate of just under 4%.  In controlling for the $13 million of elevated FDIC related revenues and interest income recoveries reported in the fourth quarter of 2015, the linked quarter growth rate was closer to 15%. This recent rate of growth in net interest income while not sustainable over the long term, reflects our focus on improving the profitability of our balance sheet and has been significantly helped by strong loan growth, the movement of cash to high quality liquid investments, the maturities of higher cost wholesale funds and December's federal funds target rate increase. Looking ahead, net interest income is expected to increase throughout 2016 as loan growth and active management of the investment portfolio impacts the size and mix of earning assets. Importantly, our performance objectives assume a 25 basis point increase in the federal funds target rate in December of 2016. We remain positioned to benefit from rising rates as shown in the box at the bottom right of Slide 11.
Slide 12 provides additional information regarding our active management of the investment portfolio. We continued to add high-quality liquid securities to our investment portfolio in the first quarter, reflecting the need for a permanent, high-quality liquid asset position in order to manage our balance sheet liquidity more effectively and in light of the liquidity coverage ratio rules. Our efforts to build out the investment portfolio are expected to add revenue in baseline and downside economic environments when compared to holding liquidity in the form of cash. 
During the first quarter, the available-for-sale investment portfolio increased $1.3 billion on average when compared to the first quarter. This average balanced growth was influenced by the $1.1. billion point-to-point increase in available-for-sale securities as well as the continued impact of purchases we made in the prior quarter. 
We continue to exercise caution with respect to the impact on overall balance sheet sensitivity, interest rate sensitivity, as we purchase fixed-rate investments and with respect to duration extension risk inherent in the investment portfolio. The securities we are adding are relatively short in duration, just over 3 years. The duration of the entire security's portfolio is about 2.6 years today. And if rates were to rise 200 basis points across the curve, our models indicate duration of the portfolio would extend only slightly to 3.1 years. 
On Page 19, we break down year-over-year loan growth in a slightly different format than we have utilized previously. The size of the bubbles on this chart represent loan portfolio size, while the position against the vertical axis represents year-over-year growth. As shown, Zions is generally growing where we want to grow where owner-occupied C&I and residential mortgage remain opportunities for additional growth. Compared to the prior quarter, period-end loans grew 7% on an annualized basis, in particular strength in C&I and term CRE. It is important to note that we have accomplished this growth while maintaining our underwriting standards.
There are 4 loan losses that have been in decline for this past year or more. And the most substantial rates of decline are in the national real estate portfolio and energy portfolio, each declining approximately 16% from the prior year-ago period.  The national real estate portfolio represents about 5% of loans. And the attrition here has resulted in a drag of just over 1 percentage point of the overall growth of the loan portfolio during the past year. We have indicated that we expected the rate of attrition to taper, and it's beginning to happen, recently declining an annualized $276 million as compared to the year-over-year decline of $415 million. On energy, as we move through redetermination on upstream energy credits, we expect paydowns due to reduced borrowing bases.
To summarize, our outlook for loan growth for the next 12 months is for an increasing portfolio, which will be in the mid-single-digit rate of growth range.
Another key component of net interest income, which is the rate or yields of a portfolio, can be found on Slide 14. This slide breaks down key components of our net interest margin. The top line is loan yield, which declined 10 basis points from the prior quarter to average 4.14%. As described in the press release, the prior quarter had a recovery of interest income of about $8 million included in the fourth quarter loan yield as well as elevated income from FDIC-supported loans. Excluding these 2 factors, the yield on the loan portfolio increased somewhat from the prior quarter lifted by the increase in benchmark rates. However, older loans booked at wider spreads are regularly maturing and continue to place pressure on loan yields. 
The securities portfolio yield improved slightly this quarter, largely due the changing composition of the portfolio as we add new bonds within our guidelines for duration and extension risk as well as the increase in rates that affected our floating-rate securities. At the bottom of the chart is a line depicting our cost of funds as a percent of earning assets, which continues to be quite low and was stable relative to prior quarter. 
The net interest margin increased to 3.35% in the first quarter, a 12 basis point increase from the prior quarter, primarily driven by the ongoing shift in earning asset composition to a higher concentration of loans and securities and a lower concentration of cash.
With that, I'll turn the call over to Scott to discuss our fee income initiative as well as provide additional detail about our energy portfolio. Scott?

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Paul. On Slide 15, we're pleased to report the continued strength in fee income growth. Because of the seasonality of the results, we think the year-over-year comparison is more relevant. Through the hard work of our employees, we were able to
componenttext:
Thank you, Paul. On Slide 15, we're pleased to report the continued strength in fee income growth. Because of the seasonality of the results, we think the year-over-year comparison is more relevant. Through the hard work of our employees, we were able to increase customer related fee income by 7% over the year-ago period. These results have been adjusted to reflect the reclassification of the expense associated with rewards programs, such as cash back, from the noninterest expense category to net against card revenue, which was done to align our accounting approach to be more comparable to the majority of banks within the industry. 
The areas experiencing the most significant growth in fee -- and customer fees included loan fees, which increased nearly $4 million or 38% from the year-ago period to equal $14 million in the first quarter 2016. Bankcard fees increased more than $2 million or 17% to equal nearly $18 million. Treasury management is our largest category of customer fee income, which increased 3% from the year-ago period to equal about $35 million. Relative to the prior quarter, we experienced an increase in dividends, although there was a valuation adjustment to one of our investments that adversely affected dividends by about $2 million.
Transitioning to energy now, obviously energy is of significant concern to many investors. And it's all an hands-on-deck effort here at Zions to do as much as possible, obviously to protect the value of principal and interest of our loans and at the same time, demonstrating our long-term commitment to our customers.
Before we dive into the numbers though, let me first address something that is the subject of much discussion on the earnings conference calls of other banks with energy exposure, the Shared National Credit exam results. As you know, this is a regulatory exam and is subject to disclosure restrictions. We have incorporated the vast majority of the results of the Shared National Credit exam in our first quarter results. And if we incorporate all of the results, the financial results of the quarter would not be materially different. 
Our grading methodology has been and continues to be consistent with regulatory guidance. As you know, -- as you may know, the Shared National Credit Program is not final. Some grades of loans where we are a participant bank are in their appeal period. Obviously, we downgrade credits based upon the Shared National Credit results where applicable. But in the Shared National Credit results are better than our internal grade, we leave the internal grade in place. So as investors looking at our financial condition, you are getting a very conservative view of the portfolio.
Let me move now to Slide 16. As you can see, our energy loan outstandings -- and also from the material in the press release increased $21 million from the prior quarter, with declines in the services portfolio, offset by some new underwriting in upstream, midstream and downstream, and a handful of defensive draws. Of course, energy loan commitments and balances are down substantially from year-ago period, and we do expect further attrition as we move through the borrowing base redetermination process. We are about 40% through the spring redetermination, and we anticipate the average borrowing base of a client to decline by about 12% to 15% relative to the fall redetermination. 
Also on Slide 16, as you can see on the right side of the slide and the chart on Page 4 of the press release, classified energy loan balances increased by $194 million from the prior quarter to equal 27% of outstanding balances. And nonaccrual loans increased by $220 million from the prior quarter to equal 10.8% of loan balances. The increase in both categories was evenly weighted between upstream loans and services, loans to energy services companies. The primary driver of these increases had to do with the severity of the commodity price volatility early in the quarter, a flattening of the Nymex strip and a continued uncertain outlook.
Turning to Slide 17, we are displaying some new information here to help investors better understand the nature of our unfunded oil and gas commitments. We have just under $400 million of unfunded loan commitments in the criticized category or just under 20% of total commitments. However, and this is very important, about 1/2 of that $400 million is unavailable to the borrower for various reasons, including borrowing base restrictions, covenant breaches or antihoarding provisions. During the quarter, we experienced 6 loans that did drop on on their lines equaling about $55 million of balances. Again, not something we are happy to see, but it is manageable. And as a senior secured lender, we feel good about our loss severity in the event that there is a default on any of these loans.
Moving on to Slide 18, it may be helpful to understand that the vast majority of our criticized and classified energy loans and even nonaccrual loans are still current on their payments. Only 9% of nonaccrual loans are past due.
Moving to Slide 19, as we all know in the first quarter, there was significant oil and gas price volatility. This volatility, combined with continuing credit-by-credit review and our top fund regression models, is leading us to update our outlook for energy loan losses. More specifically, if oil were to hover in the mid-$30s area, we currently expect losses in 2016 to be in the $100 million area. Recall our prior outlook was for a range of $75 million to $100 million for the year. Clearly, prices today are above the mid-$30 range level, however, we always want to be prepared for lower prices. During the second quarter, we will be closely monitoring the results of the spring reserve base redetermination and the actions being taken by our private equity sponsors to better inform our full year energy loss outlook.
We continue to build our energy loss reserve to a level of $214 million or more than 8% of energy balances. this is a strong reserve, particularly relative to various measures of problem loans and loss expectations. 
I'm sure we'll have questions about energy lending, but let me step back and look at the objectives we're working towards is a company.  
On Slide 20, this is summary several items we articulated at our recent Investor Day. We are fully committed to achieving positive operating leverage. And I think at this point with more than 20% year-over-year growth in PPNR, we can declare that our actions are making a very noticeable difference. We remain committed to the substantial simplification of all operational processes and the upgrading of our technology systems, which will position us with perhaps the most modern loan, deposit and customer information infrastructure in the United States. When complete, this investment will significantly simplify our back office, provide data on a real-time basis to bankers and customers, improve our new product time to market and many additional advantages.
Regarding the capital with which shareholders have entrusted us, we are targeting much more substantial returns on capital than what we -- than what can be seen today, and we are tracking well against these goals as discussed earlier. Regarding returns of capital, it is premature to discuss capital returns opportunities as we are awaiting the results of the 2016 CCAR. However, we aspire to have a much higher return of capital than experienced in the recent past.
Finally, we're absolutely committed our history of doing business with a local community bank approach. Perhaps the best acknowledgment that our commitment to doing business locally really as a strategic differentiator is the superlative results we received again this year in the nationwide survey conducted by Greenwich Research. As you know, we received more awards for the highest level of national distinction than any other bank in the United States. And we are only one of 4 banks and have performed an industry-leading levels since of this -- since the initiation of this survey.
Paul, with that, I'll turn the call back over you to conclude.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Scott. Slide 22 depicts our outlook for the next 12 months relative to the most recent quarter. We are adjusting our loan outlook to increasing due primarily to factors already discussed in earlier comments. We expect net interest income to increa
componenttext:
Thanks, Scott. Slide 22 depicts our outlook for the next 12 months relative to the most recent quarter. We are adjusting our loan outlook to increasing due primarily to factors already discussed in earlier comments. We expect net interest income to increase from the first quarter level as continued growth of loans and investment securities offset possible pressure on loan pricing. 
Our outlook does not include the effect of any future rate increases by the Federal Reserve, although we expect a benefit to annual net interest income of about $75 million to $135 million for each 100 basis point increase in rates. That's particularly focused on the short end of the curve. 
We expect a quarterly provision for loan and lease losses in 2016 that is roughly consistent with the provision taken in the first quarter of 2016, assuming current market conditions. This incorporates the maintenance of a strong reserve ratio on energy loans, although we expect energy loan balances to continue the declining trend.
We expect the noninterest income, excluding dividends and securities gains and losses, will increase slightly to moderately as we continue to focus heavily on this area. As stated previously, we are committed to holding noninterest expenses to less than $1.6 billion for 2016, excluding severance and restructuring expenses. 
The effective tax rate for the quarter was lower than the normal quarterly run rate, which was facilitated in part from the consolidation of our banking charters. We expect our effective tax rate to be in the range of 34% to 35% for the full year in 2016.
We expect preferred dividends to continue to decline. As noted last quarter, the preferred tender completed in the 4Q will reduce preferred dividends by approximately $10 million in 2016 versus 2015. I expect that you have noticed the preferred tender announced today along with this earnings release. This action, if successful, is expected to reduce our run rate preferred dividends to an annual level of roughly $45 million.
This concludes our prepared remarks. Abigail, would you please open the line for questions? Thank you.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Ken Zerbe with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Ken Zerbe with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question, I had just in terms of the provision expense, totally understand that your guidance is for sale in first quarter. First quarter is probably a little bit higher than what I think some people may have been expecting. But help us understand w
componenttext: First question, I had just in terms of the provision expense, totally understand that your guidance is for sale in first quarter. First quarter is probably a little bit higher than what I think some people may have been expecting. But help us understand why the provision expense should stay higher, given oil has made a pretty sharp improvement from $30 to call it the low $40 range. It seems that things should be getting for your energy portfolio, not necessarily worse.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ken, this is Scott. Thank you for the question. If you look back at sort of the price of oil and gas that as we entered quarter and even throughout February, it's a very dynamic process. And it's just been in the last 30 days, including the first part of
componenttext: Ken, this is Scott. Thank you for the question. If you look back at sort of the price of oil and gas that as we entered quarter and even throughout February, it's a very dynamic process. And it's just been in the last 30 days, including the first part of this quarter, that we've seen this rally. And so we're grading loans dynamically. We're evaluating the reserve dynamically. And we just -- it was such a punitive first quarter when -- from an oil and gas price volatility standpoint. Particularly the price of natural gas, the decline there was fairly new event. we just felt like the most important thing we could do would be to prepare for those first quarter oil and gas market conditions to continue. As it's turned out, they've not. The last 30 days, we've seen a really nice rebound in oil and natural gas prices.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016

componenttext: Understood. I guess maybe probably phrase it different way, if oil stays at $42, you still feel very -- and you know that for a fact, would you still guide for provision expense equal to the first quarter?

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think -- Ken, this is Harris. I think I'd just -- I'd say that we're trying to be conservative. And listen, we know that this isn't going to be smooth through the quarters. We've tried to be helpful in giving a little bit of additional guidance in terms
componenttext: I think -- Ken, this is Harris. I think I'd just -- I'd say that we're trying to be conservative. And listen, we know that this isn't going to be smooth through the quarters. We've tried to be helpful in giving a little bit of additional guidance in terms of what we think the losses in the portfolio going to be, saying -- so I think we're still comfortable there in kind of $100 million range this year. And could it come in at better than the first quarter? Sure, but it's going to -- I mean, it could bounce the other way, too. But that's just kind of our best thinking in terms of where we think losses are going to be and trying to be conservative in terms of what we think could be out there in terms of continued pressure on the reserve, if prices remain volatile and things don't continue to heal.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would also say in a market like this, you really -- we have visibility maybe 3 to 5 months out, but we don't have clear visibility all the way to end of the year even if prices were to stay at $40. And so I just -- that's why we are going to err on the
componenttext: I would also say in a market like this, you really -- we have visibility maybe 3 to 5 months out, but we don't have clear visibility all the way to end of the year even if prices were to stay at $40. And so I just -- that's why we are going to err on the side of being conservative.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think I mean, this ties into the first question  with respect to provisions. I mean, the kind of loan growth we are going to -- we've been experiencing also is going to be a factor in thinking about provisions. So it's not just energy. But it's lo
componenttext: Well, I think I mean, this ties into the first question  with respect to provisions. I mean, the kind of loan growth we are going to -- we've been experiencing also is going to be a factor in thinking about provisions. So it's not just energy. But it's loan growth for us has a little bit of a fickle kind of a thing in the last several quarters. What we can tell you is that we have seen quite a lot of consistency over the last 6 months. And so far, what we are seeing into the second quarter is encouraging, but it's hard to extrapolate that out pretty far.[ph]

componenttext: Our next question comes from Paul Miller with FBR.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey guys, it is Tim for Paul Miller. Are you seeing any second derivative impact from energy? Is it flowing through to CRE, or any other industries in any of your geographies?
componenttext: Hey guys, it is Tim for Paul Miller. Are you seeing any second derivative impact from energy? Is it flowing through to CRE, or any other industries in any of your geographies?

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll have Michael Morris, the Chief Credit Officer, speak to that.
componenttext: We'll have Michael Morris, the Chief Credit Officer, speak to that.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we're tracking both CRE and consumer very closely. We've initiated the same kind of heightened supervision and loan-level, ground-up analysis of the CRE and the consumer portfolios. And we aren't seeing large noticeable shifts or negative migration pat
componenttext: So we're tracking both CRE and consumer very closely. We've initiated the same kind of heightened supervision and loan-level, ground-up analysis of the CRE and the consumer portfolios. And we aren't seeing large noticeable shifts or negative migration patterns. We are especially watchful of our multifamily portfolio in Houston, and we are seeing some rent concessions for longer-term leases. And so that has somewhat of an effect on effective rent and NOI, but most of our properties are absorbing quite nicely. And office, there is some risk there, but the loan sizes are not significant. And the underwriting is very solid with 50% to 55% loan to cost on some of the construction loans, where they were done on a little bit of a speculative basis and we have great sponsors there. And so we have quite a bit of comfort. If we see migration in the CRE book, it will mostly be in the vast grade ranges that may be a few outliers that go to criticized.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would just add to that, that Michael mentioned our office exposure in Houston. The 2 -- the only 2 spec offices buildings we had total $36 million. One of them now is experiencing leasing, and the other actually was put to bed with a long-term amortizat
componenttext: I would just add to that, that Michael mentioned our office exposure in Houston. The 2 -- the only 2 spec offices buildings we had total $36 million. One of them now is experiencing leasing, and the other actually was put to bed with a long-term amortization as well. So we don't believe our office exposure is going to be material, although we do have exposure there. I would just say also that if you have to look at our CRE exposure in Texas relative to what we had in 2008, we have about $1 billion less total CRE exposure today than we had in 2008. We have significantly pivoted from construction lending to CRE term there. And you can see that in our numbers, we have no land A and B, and we have close to $1 billion of it going into the '08 downturn. That was principally because when you did construction loans, that you generally finance Phase 2 and Phase 3 land. And then the final point is the the amount of equity that has gone in to office, multifamily particularly, is almost double what it was in the cycle leading up to 2008. So a lot of factors that are very different today than the last cycle we went through.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would only add that with respect the consumer portfolio knock-on risks there, I would point you to Slide 26, which is new surveillance we have on high oil and gas employment counties. And we monitor FICOs there. We refresh FICOS every 2 months. And we h
componenttext: I would only add that with respect the consumer portfolio knock-on risks there, I would point you to Slide 26, which is new surveillance we have on high oil and gas employment counties. And we monitor FICOs there. We refresh FICOS every 2 months. And we haven't seen any negative migration or blips in either FICOs or delinquency rates in the consumer book.

componenttext: This is Paul. Thank you for your question. I expect while we continue to find [ph] loan pricing, I expect that the opportunity to redeploy cash into investment securities and loans will at a minimum, the net interest margin stable and perhaps could allow some modest expansion.

componenttext: Hey Paul, just a follow-up on the last question, in terms of maybe the amount of remixing you think you've got left to do, just kind of curious. The overall size of the balance sheet going forward, will we start to see that grow? Or do you think in kind of stable and continue to remix?

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd say our current plan is for a relatively stable size of the balance sheet, although I'll say about by the time we get to the end of the year, it's conceivable that the balance sheet can start modestly grow. As you know, we provided outlooks previously
componenttext: I'd say our current plan is for a relatively stable size of the balance sheet, although I'll say about by the time we get to the end of the year, it's conceivable that the balance sheet can start modestly grow. As you know, we provided outlooks previously on the amount of growth that we expected investment portfolio throughout the year, which is kind of roughly probably from here on out, kind of between $750 million or $1 billion a quarter. So depending on deposit growth and depending on our cash position, you can see us either adjust that or adjust size of the balance sheet forward.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would note the biggest -- one of the biggest onetime helpers this quarter is that about 25% of that available-for-sale portfolio is floating rate and floats . So we saw benefit this quarter related to that. As far as the rest, we continue to try to be m
componenttext: I would note the biggest -- one of the biggest onetime helpers this quarter is that about 25% of that available-for-sale portfolio is floating rate and floats . So we saw benefit this quarter related to that. As far as the rest, we continue to try to be measured as we think about, as noted in my comments, the types of bonds we're putting out and the yields of those bonds. So clearly the shape of the curve, looking ahead, the shape of the curve will clearly affect the yield of those bonds coming on.

componenttext: Well, the tendering question is difficult because as you know, kind of the more you go after these bonds, the more difficult they become hard to find. So our capital plan in 2015, we had a $300 million tender for preferred, which the announcement today kind of rounds that out for that for full $300 million. And as the capital issue and subject to CCAR, I'm really not at liberty to discuss incremental plans with respect to preferred reductions.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Back to the $100 million loss expectation, can you just give me a little bit more detail on how you got that, or why the change? I'm not sure really get it. If you were previously at 75 to 100 if oil remained at $30, what specifically make you bring that
componenttext: Back to the $100 million loss expectation, can you just give me a little bit more detail on how you got that, or why the change? I'm not sure really get it. If you were previously at 75 to 100 if oil remained at $30, what specifically make you bring that higher with oil here at $40?

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. This is similar to Ken's question, and I think in the sense that we -- that estimate really is based on our concern about the volatility of price of oil in January and February, the decline in the price of natural gas. So you may think, well, gee,
componenttext: Right. This is similar to Ken's question, and I think in the sense that we -- that estimate really is based on our concern about the volatility of price of oil in January and February, the decline in the price of natural gas. So you may think, well, gee, that was end of February, now we're in April. But we just -- we don't really pivot that fast and we -- that is pretty troubling what we saw in January and February, and it could return. We've seen $40 before. We saw it coming down. And so now we're seeing it going up, but we could be back at $30 again. So we just prefer to err on a more conservative side. I would also say on -- relates to oilfield service, the longer this goes, which it's going to go, even if prices improve, there is a general understanding in industry that the oilfield service companies will not come back as quickly as the E&P companies do. There a lot of reasons for that. And so we feel pretty confident that oilfield service will be under considerable stress for the remainder of this year and a fair amount of next year.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016

componenttext: Okay, all right.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016

componenttext: Right, right. Okay. All right. than separately on the margin, just wanted to get a little bit of additional color on how much the Fed hike actually benefited your loan yields. I mean, if you adjust for the FDIC loan impact as well as a loan recoveries that you had had previously in the fourth quarter and you adjust for that, by my math, I guess loan yields are up about 3 basis points. Is that all that you would expect from the Fed to help your loan yields? Or is there more coming?

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: As you know, particular net interest margin could really be very difficult. There a lot of countervailing things here. Obviously the Federal Reserve rate increase helped us. But I would ask you to remember and as we disclosed on our Investor Day, we gave
componenttext: As you know, particular net interest margin could really be very difficult. There a lot of countervailing things here. Obviously the Federal Reserve rate increase helped us. But I would ask you to remember and as we disclosed on our Investor Day, we gave some incremental disclosures around sensitivity of earning assets to changes in rates. And one of the things that I would point out is, we continue to have some level of loans, particularly prime-based loans, that are floored. And so they, for example, because, they are at floor rate, would not have enjoyed the kind of the dollar-for-dollar, basis point-for-basis point increase with Fed. And so we've also got some swaps on the books. those things combined with I would say continued pricing pressure, kind of led to that overall net yield improvement.

componenttext: Yes, it was interest recoveries, and there were a couple of items One was income associated with our FDIC assisted loans and also interest income recoveries from loan recoveries. And those totaled $13 million difference kind of quarter to quarter. As it looks -- as it relates to the remainder of the year invest on the kind of thing that I would expect to see. And so our outlook would not include any of that.

componenttext: It's Geoff Elliott from Autonomous Research, just a quick numbers type question. Could you break out the provision between energy and nonenergy just for the quarter? Because I'm kind of confused looking at the increase in reserves from 5% to 8% on a $2.6 billion balance of energy loans, plus the $36 million of energy-related charge-offs. I had thought with that quantum of increase in reserves, the provision would have been higher. So I'm guessing there must have been a release elsewhere.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Geoff, I'll -- I'll -- this is James Abbott. I'll just give you a quick thought is the that we -- we've -- one of the things -- one of the things we did take a look at is our reserve for unfunded lending commitments. when we let me start with that. made s
componenttext: Geoff, I'll -- I'll -- this is James Abbott. I'll just give you a quick thought is the that we -- we've -- one of the things -- one of the things we did take a look at is our reserve for unfunded lending commitments. when we let me start with that. made some fine-tuning adjustments based on the way we compute the reserve on that, particularly for smaller business customers that are less than $750,000 in size. So that was part of that allowance for credit losses and overall portfolio balance. And then we -- the reserve for loans, excluding the energy loan portfolio which is $2.6 billion. But excluding that, we do have a reserve to loan ratio of about 1.2% on that book of business. And that would compare to now net charge-offs in the quarter on that portfolio, and I would also compare it to about 70 basis points of nonaccrual loans. So it's really pretty strong reserve relative to the current credit quality positioning of that. And it's just continue to get better and better, so there's not as much support as there was 2 or 3 years ago for keeping that reserve level higher.

componenttext: Well, we're seeing essentially no charge-offs, not just this quarter, but I mean, we're seeing kind of a pattern of that. componenttext: Yes, this is Scott. The -- There was one large credit that was done there. It was a corporate debt credit. had nothing to do with energy, had nothing to do really with the Texas economy. And it's a large, a 20-year client of the bank that we were able to move a transaction out of one of global banks. They were at end of the syndications process. And the loan will pay down pretty quickly actually. We'll have about half of it amortized by the end of this year, if I remember correctly. They are seeing moderate growth in middle-market in 1- to 4-family mortgages, so middle-market commercial lending and 1- to 4-family mortgages. And a portion of their real estate portfolio funded just basically related to construction of the construction portfolio.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016

componenttext: All right.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And in terms of the outlook, having gone through these declines before down there, they are -- their risk filters are very well tuned and have been quite frankly for about 2 years. But there's a lot of good market share movement that will go on during a p
componenttext: And in terms of the outlook, having gone through these declines before down there, they are -- their risk filters are very well tuned and have been quite frankly for about 2 years. But there's a lot of good market share movement that will go on during a period like this. It happens in most other periods like this, and so there will be opportunity. There will also be energy underwriting that will take place as distressed assets are purchased by new acquirers and as companies are put together, merged. So there will be new energy underwriting that probably will begin to manifest itself in the second half of the year.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, maybe just a follow-up on that. Can you just kind of talk about if that happens, what your appetite would be for taking on new energy loans right at this part of the cycle?
componenttext: Okay, maybe just a follow-up on that. Can you just kind of talk about if that happens, what your appetite would be for taking on new energy loans right at this part of the cycle?

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I would say that our appetite would be totally based on normal credit underwriting criteria with again our full risk filters on. But if you were going to underwrite a reserve base oil and gas transaction, today would be a moderately good time to do
componenttext: Well, I would say that our appetite would be totally based on normal credit underwriting criteria with again our full risk filters on. But if you were going to underwrite a reserve base oil and gas transaction, today would be a moderately good time to do that. And so there will be good transactions that have presented themselves and will present themselves. On the oilfield service side, I would say the odds of that happening are much lower. We certainly you not ascribe much value to borrowing bases, et cetera, et cetera. And the equity levels would be very high. The kind of financing we do there would probably generally be receivable based to more than anything else. But the new underwritings in energy will be more reserve-based -- and midstream than anything else.

componenttext: I wanted to ask bit about expenses just to change the subject a little bit. Personnel expenses are about 60% of the composition, and year-over-year, it grew about 6%. About half of that was related to, I think, moving those retirement-based awards up one quarter, but we're still seeing about 3% growth. Do we think that as you move forward, we should be able to see some of the initiatives kick in, and maybe that growth rate begin to slow down a little bit?

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think -- well listen, I think you're going to see it pretty flat and perhaps down a little bit. I mean we do have underlying initiatives. We are clear I think at the outset those targets are gross targets, not net. And so you have normal kind of me
componenttext: Yes, I think -- well listen, I think you're going to see it pretty flat and perhaps down a little bit. I mean we do have underlying initiatives. We are clear I think at the outset those targets are gross targets, not net. And so you have normal kind of merit increases in compensation. We have a little higher incentive compensation accruals here in the first quarter than I think we had a year ago. And all of that subject to kind of continued performance for the year, so that could be still a variable and will be. And I would also note that I mean there some job categories where the wage pressures, particularly in IT kind of related areas, I mean there are a few kind specialized areas where the pressures are very real. So our hope would be to keep those flat to down I think consistent with  at the end of the day, we're really keeping an eye on the $1.6 billion and efficiency ratio number, and that's what I'm most comfortable affirming. I think we're on a pretty strong track to accomplish those goals.

componenttextpreview: Yes, yes. So generally speaking on the reserve base side, it's really kind of more of a marking to market, if you will. And on the oilfield service side, the losses there generally have related to if a private equity firm that may choose not to play forwa
componenttext: Yes, yes. So generally speaking on the reserve base side, it's really kind of more of a marking to market, if you will. And on the oilfield service side, the losses there generally have related to if a private equity firm that may choose not to play forward and kind of forces the situation into bankruptcy and liquidation -- and I think that will continue to be the trend. I think the losses on the oilfield service side will be lumpier. And it will be because they just can't continue, and so that just accelerates the home realization process. Whereas on the reserve base side, it's going to be kind of dribs and drabs here and there. And I don't think we'll have any real significant large pieces because we have no second liens and we have no high-yield debt. In general, we had very conservatively underwritten senior pieces.

componenttext: I just wanted to revisit the defensive draws. I think you said there were 5 or 6 of them this quarter. Was that more out of the the services or the upstream book? And then what can you guys do to mitigate that? Or kind of once it's there, how do you cure it?

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, first of all, the -- in terms of kind of the second part of your question in terms of mitigating it, most of banks are putting in antihoarding provisions. And you don't have to wait for the maturity of the transaction to do that. It's generally almo
componenttext: Well, first of all, the -- in terms of kind of the second part of your question in terms of mitigating it, most of banks are putting in antihoarding provisions. And you don't have to wait for the maturity of the transaction to do that. It's generally almost everything in the energy space right now is being amended, renegotiated, et cetera every 6 months or so. And so we're having pretty good luck in getting these antihoarding provisions in, number one. Secondly, generally speaking, when it's one of our strong private equity firms that's involved, the odds are much less likely that they'll try defensive draws, that's been what we've experienced. and the answer to the first part of your question, I mentioned there was about $50 million in defensive draws, one of which is paid back or will pay back shortly partially. And it's about 50% that -- by company, it's about 50% upstream, 50% services.
