headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to your Zions Second Quarter Earnings Results Webcast. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. I would like to introduce your host for today's conference, James Abbott, Director
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to your Zions Second Quarter Earnings Results Webcast. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. I would like to introduce your host for today's conference, James Abbott, Director of Investor Relations. Sir, you may begin.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Esther, and good evening. We welcome you to this conference call to discuss our 2016 second quarter earnings. Our primary participants today will be Harris Simmons, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; Scott McLean, President and Chief Operati
componenttext:
Thank you, Esther, and good evening. We welcome you to this conference call to discuss our 2016 second quarter earnings. Our primary participants today will be Harris Simmons, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; Scott McLean, President and Chief Operating Officer; and Paul Burdiss, Chief Financial Officer.
I would like to remind you that during this call, we will be making forward-looking statements, although actual results may differ materially. We encourage you to review the disclaimer in the press release or the slide deck dealing with forward-looking information, which apply equally to statements made in this call. A copy of the full earnings release as well as the supplemental slide deck are available at zionsbancorporation.com and we will be referring to the slide during this call. The earnings release, the related slide presentation and this earnings call contain several references to non-GAAP measures, including preprovision net revenue and the efficiency ratio, which are common industry terms used by investors and financial services analysts. Certain of these non-GAAP measures are key inputs into Zions' management compensation and are used in Zions' strategic goals that have been and may continue to be articulated to investors. Therefore, the use of such non-GAAP measures are believed by management to be a substantial interest to the consumers of these financial disclosures and are used predominantly throughout the disclosures. The full reconciliation of the difference between such measures and GAAP financials is provided within the published document and participants are encouraged carefully to use this reconciliation. We intend to limit the length of this call to 1 hour, which will include a question-and-answer section. [Operator Instructions]
I will now turn the time over to Harris Simmons.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much, James, and welcome all of you to our call this afternoon to discuss our 2016 second quarter results.On Slide 3 for some highlights for the quarter. Earnings per share increased to $0.44 from a loss of $0.01 per share a year ago. By
componenttext:
Thank you very much, James, and welcome all of you to our call this afternoon to discuss our 2016 second quarter results.
On Slide 3 for some highlights for the quarter. Earnings per share increased to $0.44 from a loss of $0.01 per share a year ago. By using the same adjustments that we used to compute our efficiency ratio, which primarily to adjust for the loss on the sale of our remaining collateralized debt obligation portfolio a year ago, and the preferred stock redemption expense in the second quarter of this year, earnings per share increased nearly 17% over the prior year second quarter.
We're pleased with the continued trend of strong increases in preprovision net revenue, which is the result of solid net interest income growth and adjusted noninterest expense levels that were well controlled and that remained within the parameters of our stated expense initiatives.
Adjusted for the same items mentioned earlier, we achieved positive operating leverage for the fifth consecutive quarter. We're tracking well with our efficiency initiative, with the efficiency ratio declining to 64.5% in the second quarter from 68.5% in the prior quarter. Recall that our goal for 2016 was to achieve an efficiency ratio of less than 66%. We also experienced improved loan growth. For the second quarter, loans increased 2.6% prior quarter, so it was a quarter for loan growth.
Credit quality is a little bit of the tale of 2 cities. We consistently try to very transparent about the credit quality challenges of the oil and gas portfolio through this energy cycle. It remains challenged and we'll discuss that in a little more detail later.
Outside of oil and gas, the loan net charge-offs were only $1 million on a portfolio of approximately $40 billion of non-oil and gas loans. So when you get outside of the oil and gas portfolio, we are actually really, really pleased with the quality that we're seeing there.
Turning to Slide 4, our adjusted preprovision net revenue has improved by a strong 32% over the past year. The adjustments to the GAAP numbers are detailed at the end of the slide deck but the major exclusion of the effect of securities gains and losses. We have been -- and we've been successful in improving both revenue and trimming expenses. We expect to continue to post continued growth and adjusted preprovision growth revenue. Although we expect the rate of growth for the next 12 months to be somewhat less than the very strong 32% we saw this quarter.
On Slide 5, we display our loans and deposits. Relative to the first quarter, we experienced an acceleration of loan growth in the second quarter with loan sales from investment increasing 2.6% as previously noted. Deposit balance has increased an annualized 3.1% from the prior quarter without an increase in the cost of deposits.
On Slide 6, there's a graphical representation of our loan growth by type. The size of the circles represents the relative size of the loan types. We remain pleased with growth in areas that are targeted for growth. Although we've experienced strong growth in terms of commercial real estate, we expect growth in that category to moderate going forward. We also expect nonenergy commercial and industrial loans and residential mortgage loans to experience solid growth to be the primary driver for loan growth over the next few quarters.
We continue to expect a decline in the national real estate portfolio that we discussed on prior occasions. I might add one additional note regarding overall loan growth going forward. The second and fourth quarters are typically seasonally a little stronger than the first and third quarters, so while we're particularly pleased with the second quarter's growth, we expect more tempered growth in the third quarter.
Moving to Slide 7. We are well on our way to achieving another key measure of our commitment to shareholders, which is to reduce the efficiency ratio in less than 66% for the full year of 2016. As noted year-to-date, efficiency ratio is 66.5%; quarterly level was 64.5%. I'd also note that we're achieving all of this while investing substantially in enabling new technology and modernizing our core deposit loan assistance, which we expect will provide benefits for years to come and will be a really important competitive strength for us once we complete these projects over the next 2 or 3 years.
On Slide 8 is our scorecard highlighting the commitments we made to shareholders back in June of 2015. I'm pleased with the progress made in the number of these areas in a relatively short period of time. All of these major initiatives are tracking on targeted budgets and time lines. I'm pleased to report that we've completed the preferred equity dividend reduction a year earlier than our commitment.
My concluding comment will be regarding credit quality. In previous presentations to investors, I've highlighted designs loan quality is measured by net loan losses has been superior to most regional peer banks through multiple cycles. This is largely attributable to the collateralized nature of our lending. On Slide 9, my high-level comment on energy lending is that we have turned from cautious to cautiously optimistic. We believe there will continue to be losses in that portfolio but with our strong reserve, we presently expect to experience average quarterly provisioning for loan losses of the next year, a level that is relatively consistent with that of the second quarter. Excluding energy loans, credit quality is really strong across the company as noted and this is true by both loan type and geography. About $40 billion of the $42.5 billion loan portfolio consist of nonenergy loans, and the total net charge-off ratio on that portfolio during the last 5 quarters has a medium -- a median of only 1 basis point annualized. Nonperforming assets were stable relative to the prior quarter, and the nonenergy classified loans declined and 90-plus day delinquency also declined. So some good metrics there.
With that overview, I'll turn the call over to Paul Burgess to review the financial results. Paul?

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Harris and good evening, everyone. I'll begin on Slide 10. For the second part of 2016, Zions reported net earnings applicable to common shareholders of $91 million or $0.44 per share. Relative to the second quarter of last year, net interest i
componenttext:
Thank you, Harris and good evening, everyone. I'll begin on Slide 10. For the second part of 2016, Zions reported net earnings applicable to common shareholders of $91 million or $0.44 per share. Relative to the second quarter of last year, net interest income increased about $41 million or 9.7%. Customer-related fees, which is the bulk of noninterest income, improved about 5% from the second quarter of 2015.
At $382 million, noninterest expense was lower in the second quarter of 2016 when compared to the year ago quarter. Although the year ago quarter included seasonal stock-based compensation which was incurred in the first quarter in 2016 for this fiscal year. However, even considering this, we continue to make solid progress on our noninterest expense commitment.
Turning to the provision for loan and lease losses. At our last earnings call, we provided an outlook for provisions for the next 4 quarters that were consistent with the first quarter of 2016. Overall, loan losses in the second quarter were roughly in line with that forecast. Also in the second quarter, we observed higher and more stable energy commodity prices, improved sentiment by oil and gas borrowers and sponsors and improved capital market activity in that industry. However, because we remain cautious on the outlook for losses in that portfolio, we maintained the dollar amount of the oil and gas reserves. The resulting reserves, as a percentage of oil and gas loans, increased slightly as a result of the decline in oil and gas balances outstanding. Additionally, continued improvements in the rest of the loan portfolio and minimal non-oil and gas net charge-off have resulted in lower overall reserve and provision levels in the second quarter when compared to the first quarter.
Slide 11 outlines our recent trends in net interest income which continued to demonstrate strength in the second quarter. On a year-over-year basis, net interest income was up 9.7% when compared to the second quarter of 2015, driven by growth in loans and in the investment portfolio. The linked-quarter increase was due to several various factors, most of the increase was due to strong average loan growth and continued deployment of cash into higher yielding, highly liquid investment securities. We remain positioned to benefit from rising rates, particularly short-term rates as shown in the box at the bottom right-hand side of this might. Although we have deployed a substantial amount of cash into securities and loans, the interest rate characteristics of those assets combined with continued deposit growth have resulted in a somewhat stable interest rate sensitivity position. Using the midpoint of the range shown, a 25 basis point rate increase would improve annual net interest income by $25 million to $30 million, we expect. As a reminder, our performance objectives that were initially communicated in June 2015 assumed 1 additional 25 basis point -- funds target rate increase in December of 2016. Recently, the market was priced again about a 50% -- 50% chance of this occurring, approximately back to where it was prior to and up substantially from the low of 8% in the wake of the Brexit vote.
Slide 12 provides additional information regarding our active management of investment portfolio. We continue to add high-quality liquid securities to our investment portfolio in the second quarter, reflecting the need for a permanent high-quality liquid asset position in order to manage our balance sheet liquidity more effectively and in light of liquidity coverage ratio rules. Our efforts to build out the investment portfolio are expected to add revenue in the current and downside economic environments when compared to holding liquidity in the form of cash. During the second quarter, the available-for-sale investment portfolio increased $879 million on average when compared to the prior quarter. We continue to exercise caution with respect to the impact on overall balance sheet interest rate sensitivity as we purchase fixed-rate investments, and with respect to the duration extension risk inherent in the investment portfolio.
The mortgage-backed securities we are adding a relatively short in duration, right around 3 years, with duration extension risk being only about 0.5 year if rates increased by 200 basis points. The duration of the entire securities portfolio, including our floating-rate SBA securities, is about 2.7 years today. If rates were to rise 200 basis points across the curve, our model estimates that duration of the portfolio would extend only slightly to 2.8 years. A minor footnote to the disclosure on this extension risk. In previous iterations, we assumed a static prepayment rate for the SBA securities. In April, we made a change to the model to assume dynamic prepayment speed assumptions and these securities behave in the opposite fashion when compared to residential mortgage-backed securities. We believe the SBA securities are expected to generally experience higher prepayment as rates rise. Thus, in some sense, offsetting the minor extension risk continued within the residential mortgage-backed securities portfolio.
Another key component of net interest income, the rate or yields of the investment portfolio and the loan production, can be found on Slide 13. This slide breaks down key composite of our net interest margin. Top line is the loan yield, which expanded 2 basis points from the prior quarter to average 4.16%, and this was primarily attributable to commercial real estate loans that matured or repriced during the quarter. The securities portfolio yield dipped this quarter largely due to increased premium amortization, which was in turn due to higher prepayment rates. We expect some additional pressure on the securities portfolio yield in 2016 as a result of the recent increase in mortgage refinancing activity. At the bottom of this chart is a line depicting our cost of funds as a percent of our earning assets, which continues to be quite low, at 16 basis points and was stable relative to the prior quarter. The combination of all of these components and the continued deployment of cash into better yielding, highly liquid investments resulted in a 4 basis point increase in the net interest margin this quarter. Although we do expect increased premium amortization from the residential mortgage-backed securities portfolio, as well as increased refinance activity on a portion of our residential loan portfolio, we estimate the effect on the net interest margin to be less than 5 basis points in the near term. This may be offset by continued shift of cash into loans and securities. 
Over the longer term, as cash balances reach minimal levels, we expect to require additional funding for loan growth. Although most sources of funding would result in lower incremental margins per dollar of loans produced, the overall effect could be a modestly compressing net interest margin but a continued increase in net interest income.
Turning to Slide 14 and noninterest income. Because of the seasonality of results, we think year-over-year comparison is most relevant. We were able to increase customer-related fee income by 5% over the year-ago period. The areas experiencing the most significant growth include treasury management, which was up 8%; wealth management, which was up 9%; and mortgage, up 16%. Notably in the current quarter, there was a $1.7 million gain in the loan sales and servicing line item that is related to the increased valuation of mortgage loans held for sale at quarter-end. That valuation increase was attributable to the sharp decline of interest rates at the end of the month of June. As such, we do not expect that specific need to be repeated, although we continue to expect relatively strong growth in our mortgage business.
Noninterest expense on Slide 15 declined 4.3% from the prior year and is adjusted for items such as severance as displayed in the GAAP to non-GAAP table in the back of our slide deck. The decline was 2.6% from the year ago period. Although I will note that about half of that improvement is due the timing of stock-based compensation, which we have had discussed previously.
For 2016, we are tracking to an adjusted noninterest expense level that is consistent with our stated goal of less than $1.58 billion. Relative to the prior quarter, the decline in noninterest expense was predominantly due to a decline in salary and benefits. As you know in the first quarter, we incur seasonal expenses, which taper or are not present for the balance of the year. Specifically, severance declined $3 million, stock-based compensation and retirement plan matching declined $9 million and payroll taxes declined $4 million when we observe the second quarter compared to the first quarter.
Turning to Slide 16. We're pleased to announce last Friday that we are actively pursuing our capital plan. To that end, the board has increased the quarterly dividend rate by 33% to $0.08 per share. Additionally, we have been authorized to initiate our common equity buyback plan, which calls for $180 million over the course of the next 4 quarters. By doing so, we will be actively managing our capital to a lower level in order to align the capital structure to the risk profile of the company. We expect this to enhance return on equity as well as accelerate the growth rate of earnings per share.
With that, I'll turn the call over to Scott McLean to discuss energy lending and recap our commitment to investors. Scott?

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Paul. On Slide 17, we show on the left side as well as of the slide, the oil and gas those broken down by upstream, services and other. Other is essentially midstream and downstream. Energy loan out dialing balances decreased about $73 million
componenttext:
Thank you, Paul. On Slide 17, we show on the left side as well as of the slide, the oil and gas those broken down by upstream, services and other. Other is essentially midstream and downstream. Energy loan out dialing balances decreased about $73 million from the prior quarter with declines principally in upstream and services -- in the services portfolio, offset by a small amount of growth in the midstream portfolio.
Parenthetically, you will note on Slide 22, that energy loan commitments declined more than that $270 million from the prior quarter and are down $875 million from the prior year.
Looking at the problem loan metrics again on Slide 17 for the oil and gas portfolio, classified energy loan balances increased about $99 million drink the quarter. This compares to a $194 million increase in quarter 1, which indicates a slowing trend in new problem outstanding. Also of note, and easier to see on Slide 22, criticized balances actually declined $20 million from Q1.
Finally, nonaccrual loan balances were flat relative to the prior quarter. It may be helpful to understand that the vast majority of criticized, classified and even nonaccrual loans are still current on their contractual payments.
On Slide 18, regarding our loss expectations. If oil were to hold in mid-40s or higher, we currently expect energy losses for 2016 to be approximately $125 million. We expect most of these losses to come from our services portfolio, an area where a substantial number of borrowers remain challenged. Although oil and gas net loan losses may remain elevated, we anticipate the second half of 2016 to be less than the first half of 2016 in terms of energy net charge-offs, which were approximately $73 million in the first half of 2016. Most of the balance of the loans that we flagged as high risk for loss already have substantial specific reserves set aside against them. As Harris noted earlier, we have approved our outlook and energy to what we would describe as cautiously optimistic. Our conversations with borrowers, sponsors suggests that sentiment has improved, as you can imagine, given the increase in the underlying oil and gas commodity prices.
Also highlighted on this slide, we maintained our energy loan loss reserve relatively flat, equaling slightly more than $200 million and more than 8% of outstanding balances. We consider this very strong reserve, particularly relative to various measures of problem loans and loss expectations.
If you turn to Slide 19, this is the last of our key objectives and our commitments in our fundamental commitment to shareholders. We're fully committed to achieving positive operating leverage we described. And I think at this point, with more than 30% year-over-year growth in PPNR, we can declare that our actions are making a very noticeable difference. We remain committed to the substantial simplification of all operational processes and upgrading our technology systems, which will position us with perhaps the most modern loan, deposit and customer information infrastructure in the United States. When complete, this investment will significantly simplify our back office, provide data on a real-time basis to bankers and customers, improve our new product time to market, position us well to more aggressively adopt, enhance digital capabilities and many additional advantages. Regarding the capital with which shareholders have entrusted us, we're targeting much more substantial returns on capital than what can be seen today, and we are tracking well with those goals as discussed earlier.
Regarding returns of capital, we're pleased with the non-objection by the Federal Reserve to increase our returns of capital to shareholders. Finally, we're absolutely committed to our history of doing business with local communities bank approach. Perhaps the best acknowledgment that our commitment to doing business locally really is the strategic differentiator is the superlative results we received again this year in the nationwide survey conducted by Greenwich research. As you know, we received more awards for the highest level of national distinction than any other bank, and we are only one of four banks that have performed at industry-leading level since the initiation of this survey approximately 8 years ago.
Paul, with that, I'd like to turn the call back to you.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Scott. Slide 20 depicts our outlook for the next 12 months relative to the most recent quarter. We are downgrading our loan growth outlook to moderately increasing from increasing due primarily to internal decisions to constrain some of the commer
componenttext:
Thanks, Scott. Slide 20 depicts our outlook for the next 12 months relative to the most recent quarter. We are downgrading our loan growth outlook to moderately increasing from increasing due primarily to internal decisions to constrain some of the commercial real estate growth we have recently experienced. Although the quality of what we're producing remains very strong, we are going to remain disciplined in our concentration of risk management avoiding too much in any one geography, loan type or single vintage. We expect net interest income to increase in the mid to high single-digit growth rate, driven primarily by loan growth and additional growth in the investment portfolio. Given the right market conditions, we may also add interest rate swaps to assist with the reduction of our asset sensitivity. Although our efficiency target includes the assumption of 1 additional quarter point rate hike, we believe we can achieve a mid to high single-digit growth rate in net interest income without an increase in the target federal funds rate.
We expect a quarterly provision for credit loss, which includes the provision for both funded loans and unfunded loan commitments, to be roughly stable relative to the second quarter, assuming no significant adverse change in market conditions.
We expect that customer related noninterest income, which includes dividend income and securities gains and losses, will increase slightly to moderately as we continue to focus heavily on this area. We continue to be encouraged by the efforts of our teammates to manage our cost of doing business. Our collective efforts allow Zions to remain on track towards our goal of adjusted noninterest expense at less than $1.58 billion for 2016.
For the next 4 quarters, we expect noninterest expense to run approximately similar to the first half of 2016 annualized, with similar seasonal variation in the first quarter of '17 as is seen in the first quarter of '16. The effective tax rate for the second quarter return to its more typical level. Recall in the first quarter, we recognized a one-time tax credit. We expect our effective tax rate to be in the range of 34% to 36% over the next 12 months.
We expect preferred dividends to continue to decline, with the successful tender completed in the second quarter, preferred dividends are expected to be approximately $45 million over the next 12 months.
This concludes our prepared remarks. Esther, would you please open the line for questions?

componenttextpreview: This is Michael Morris, I'm the Chief Credit Officer. I'll comment on that briefly. The term commercial real estate growth that we saw in Q2 was driven partly by slower paydowns, some conversion of construction to term loan, and other value-add transactio
componenttext: This is Michael Morris, I'm the Chief Credit Officer. I'll comment on that briefly. The term commercial real estate growth that we saw in Q2 was driven partly by slower paydowns, some conversion of construction to term loan, and other value-add transactions in the income property space. All of which are well underwritten with safe TCRs, well-defined and lower LTVs, equity and transactions. So that was a little bit unusual but we're very satisfied with the credit quality of that particular portion of the loan growth and CRE.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Geoff, this is James Abbott, I might just add a couple. We looked at the underwriting statistics of the production for the quarter, and just in terms of a general comment, the average loan to value is in the mid-50s and the average debt service covera
componenttext: And Geoff, this is James Abbott, I might just add a couple. We looked at the underwriting statistics of the production for the quarter, and just in terms of a general comment, the average loan to value is in the mid-50s and the average debt service coverage ratio was would be about 2x coverage, so a very good underlying statistics on the growth that we did see. But again, as we mentioned earlier, we're concerned about too much in one 1 [indiscernible] 1 particular loan classification.

componenttext: Geoff, this is Scott. I would also note that geographically, it was a nice dispersion across California, Arizona, Nevada and Washington, with a small modest amount of growth in Texas on the term side. But the term has been pretty well-balanced across the portfolio.

componenttextpreview: I thought it was pretty solid performance on the fee side. Is it still early yet or are you starting to see some results from some of your initiatives there? And excluding the loan sale valuation thing you talked about, is this a pretty good base to build
componenttext: I thought it was pretty solid performance on the fee side. Is it still early yet or are you starting to see some results from some of your initiatives there? And excluding the loan sale valuation thing you talked about, is this a pretty good base to build off going forward here?

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Joe, this is Scott. And yes, I think our initiatives are showing nice progress. Our treasury management activities are still -- it's our largest fee income stream. It's about 30% and it's growing in the mid-to high single-digit rates, which is really good
componenttext: Joe, this is Scott. And yes, I think our initiatives are showing nice progress. Our treasury management activities are still -- it's our largest fee income stream. It's about 30% and it's growing in the mid-to high single-digit rates, which is really good for that business. Our other bank card products, business card, consumer card are growing at high single-digit rates which is, we've talked about repeatedly over the last couple of years, basically trying to get the same sort of penetration in our other markets that we currently achieve for those products in Zions First National Bank, our bank in Utah. And then wealth management, which we've been concentrating on, it's growing high single digits. Mortgage, the fee income, going component is not growing even though our volume -- origination volume is up -- it was up 30% last year. Our origination volume will be up about 30% this year. But we are keeping more of that on the books. And consequently, it's not having the fee income benefit that we thought it would. But those would be just some things I would highlight.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And I guess as a follow-up along those lines, I saw you purchased $104 million of loans or so in the quarter. I was curious what drove that decision? And do you see doing more of that going forward?

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: It was a modest purchase with a really strong correspondent we have a lot of respect for. We are, as you know, still significantly underrated on exposure to 1- to 4-family. And even though we're originating really nice volumes with our mortgage initiative
componenttext: It was a modest purchase with a really strong correspondent we have a lot of respect for. We are, as you know, still significantly underrated on exposure to 1- to 4-family. And even though we're originating really nice volumes with our mortgage initiative, we thought at least having this as a alternate source was -- is a good thing. The yields are significantly higher than what we could buy into our investment portfolio. And the credit statistics are on par with our own originations with yields principally on par with our own originations. So it's just a real nice relationship and we'll probably continue it at a very modest pace. But it's clearly not a key driver of our results.

componenttext: I'm sorry, how much further the cash balance to come down. So we're going to continue to work that down as we invest. Obviously be deposits ebbs and flows are going to impact that. It's hard for me to give you a precise number, although I will say that despite the very good loan growth we've had in the first half of the year, we continue to be on track with respect to our investment portfolio targets, which is purchasing another sort of $1.5 billion or so over the next 2 quarters.

componenttextpreview: If you're speaking about the -- if the question is on the cash balance, I would expect to continue to whittle that down. Ultimately, as I said in my prepared remarks, I do expect for us to get in a new position where we are going to incrementally go out a
componenttext: If you're speaking about the -- if the question is on the cash balance, I would expect to continue to whittle that down. Ultimately, as I said in my prepared remarks, I do expect for us to get in a new position where we are going to incrementally go out and need to fund loan growth. When that happens, then you can assume that our cash balance has reached sort of it's low point and the point that we're most comfortable with.

componenttext: On the expense side, you guys are doing a good job and certainly marching that sub-$158 billion this year. I just wondering you gave that plus $158 billion number for next year a long while ago, and you've tracked so much better already. Just wondering what kind of line of sight you have on that it this point. And if you think you can maybe have that with more flexibility than you had originally thought on any increases that would have come after this year.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016

componenttext: Right. This is Scott and we -- basically what we said was sub-$1,580,000,000 for this year and slightly increasing in 2017. And I think fundamentally, we feel we're going to be able to stay fairly close to the $1,580,000,000 next year as well. So we're continuing to find new ways to reduce expense in light of -- and fund those areas of growing.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I expect we'll have a little more to say about this as we get closer may be towards the end of the year. But -- so I would read what Scott just said. I mean, to the extent that it's north of $1,580,000,000, there won't be much in excess of that. Maybe bet
componenttext: I expect we'll have a little more to say about this as we get closer may be towards the end of the year. But -- so I would read what Scott just said. I mean, to the extent that it's north of $1,580,000,000, there won't be much in excess of that. Maybe better than it but I think it's the literally small [ph].

componenttext: And -- yes, okay, well I'll ask my follow-up just to relate to it. If you were to do better than it, do you think it's because you're finding more or is it because the crusting of some of the prior spend is just coming in better-than-expected?

componenttext: No, I think it would be principally be because we're finding more opportunities to simplify how we do business and those opportunities we're digging into literally every day we have been can best in the adoption of common practices and back office activities, the middle office activities is just been investing continuing to show us opportunities to reduce cost. So it'd be more related to that in the kind of cresting of any previous activities.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016

componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Marty Mosby with Vining Sparks.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask you as you think back over the last year in your incremental purchase of $5 billion, how much do you think you've increased the benefit from that versus doing it today? So since we had higher rates over the last year, if you look at the 10
componenttext: I wanted to ask you as you think back over the last year in your incremental purchase of $5 billion, how much do you think you've increased the benefit from that versus doing it today? So since we had higher rates over the last year, if you look at the 10 basis points for every $5 billion would be $5 million that you'll be able to generate annually. So how much do you think now you're buying compared to what you were buying yields about a year ago?

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Are you asking about incremental yield bonds we're putting on?
componenttext: Are you asking about incremental yield bonds we're putting on?

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: The difference between what you bought over the last year and what you're buying today.
componenttext: The difference between what you bought over the last year and what you're buying today.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. There are a couple of things there. One is rate and one is volume. And I think you can probably look at MBS rates in the marketplace for kind of the 5-year treasury and kind of come up with an estimate of that differential and yields between what we'
componenttext: Yes. There are a couple of things there. One is rate and one is volume. And I think you can probably look at MBS rates in the marketplace for kind of the 5-year treasury and kind of come up with an estimate of that differential and yields between what we're buying then and what we're buying now. The other thing I would point out though, and it's -- I'm sure you've noticed, is that we bought a lot of bonds in the first half of last year. We did okay in the first quarter. In the second quarter, we really slowed that down. We slowed it down because of the shape of the curve. And I think we've been pretty clear about telegraphing our intentions while we need to continue to put money to work, we're trying to be thoughtful about the timing of those purchases. And I think your question kind of points specifically to any incremental value when we have credit there. So I can't give you kind of a specific dollar amount, Marty, but I think it's probably pretty easy to triangulate on when you look at the change of the market in the volume of what we bought over the last or some last year.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I want to triangulate. I get $20 million to $25 million annual earnings that you actually generated by starting about a year ago. So the other I was wondering is it looks like you're starting to use a little bit of municipals. Is that something you'r
componenttext: Yes, I want to triangulate. I get $20 million to $25 million annual earnings that you actually generated by starting about a year ago. So the other I was wondering is it looks like you're starting to use a little bit of municipals. Is that something you're adding more of? Are you finding some opportunities there? Then kind of an interesting little twist on what you're doing securities portfolio and kind of alleviates some of the pressure on yields that you would be getting right now.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have a very long and successful history in dealing with municipalities and providing credit to the local markets. This is critically important to what we do as a very locally oriented bank. I think we're successful across our footprint, have been for o
componenttext: We have a very long and successful history in dealing with municipalities and providing credit to the local markets. This is critically important to what we do as a very locally oriented bank. I think we're successful across our footprint, have been for of very long time, decades, and continue to be. So I think what that what you're seeing there, Marty, is just a continuation of the success that we've had as an organization.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would add that it is something that we're very focused on trying to step up somewhat and do more of this particularly with smaller municipalities where we think the risk reward kind of trade-off is quite nice. And whereas Paul indicates, we have a very
componenttext: I would add that it is something that we're very focused on trying to step up somewhat and do more of this particularly with smaller municipalities where we think the risk reward kind of trade-off is quite nice. And whereas Paul indicates, we have a very long, solid track record, yes so there's some focus there. The growth you're seeing isn't primarily a result of that push yet but I'm hoping that over the next couple of years, you'll start to see more of that.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then, Harris, one last question. When you look at the excess capital, we estimate it to be about $1 billion. Now that we're going into the next phase, which is being able to pull some of that capital and give it back to shareholders, if you had a free
componenttext: And then, Harris, one last question. When you look at the excess capital, we estimate it to be about $1 billion. Now that we're going into the next phase, which is being able to pull some of that capital and give it back to shareholders, if you had a free reign, looks like we went back to the days where you could pretty much look at your excess capital and do something with it. It would add 150 basis points to your returns if you could deal with that $1 billion. What would you do if you didn't have the constraints that you have today? I mean, how would you strategically deal with that at this point?

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the first answer is -- I mean, clearly, the world has changed a lot from the days when we had free reign. But your posting a hypothetical. I guess I would say clearly, we would use everything we've done in building capabilities to stress tes
componenttext: Well, I think the first answer is -- I mean, clearly, the world has changed a lot from the days when we had free reign. But your posting a hypothetical. I guess I would say clearly, we would use everything we've done in building capabilities to stress testing the model to think about risk, particularly in a downturn to inform how we think about capital. And there are a lot of things that we have dealt the risk management-wise here in the last 5 or 6 to 7 years that I think are actually really useful tools. Yes, I think we would agree that we've got more capital. We're at the north end of where our peers are. I would note that we'll always going to be probably kind of to the strong side so long as we have somewhat higher exposures to both commercial real estate and energy. I mean, we know that those are both segments where you could see maybe a little more cyclicality among other things. And so as you took all of the limits off, this wouldn't be a raise to the bottom,  if you will, in terms of rating your capital. But we want to kind of thoughtfully rightsize our capital and go into it. And I think it got -- gives us a lot of flexibility in terms of what we can do. I don't know, I hope that's helpful. I -- I'm -- we know that the have more preferred than what probably need right now. That's something that we talk about and we continue to opportunistically deal with. But our common equity too, we're heavy and that something that's increasingly, I think you'll see is working at. It's very much on the line.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Paul Miller with FBR & Co.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Paul Miller with FBR & Co.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. On top of the question on capital, I mean you've done a great job over the last 12 to 18 months getting your expenses down, getting the preferred down and whatnot. But your ROEs -- and you do have more capital than you need, but your ROEs tend to be
componenttext: Yes. On top of the question on capital, I mean you've done a great job over the last 12 to 18 months getting your expenses down, getting the preferred down and whatnot. But your ROEs -- and you do have more capital than you need, but your ROEs tend to be stuck in that middle single digit and some of that is the credit cost associated with oil and gas. What is your ultimate goal, what is your ultimate goal relatively speaking with regard to ROEs to get it into the -- how are you going to get it into the 10% to 12% range?

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think -- and I'd say another goal is over the next couple of years to get up around 10%. And we think that that's doable. There is some additional reduction in preferred that would help, I mean, cost of cost of preferred is a drag to the ROE. I wo
componenttext: Well, I think -- and I'd say another goal is over the next couple of years to get up around 10%. And we think that that's doable. There is some additional reduction in preferred that would help, I mean, cost of cost of preferred is a drag to the ROE. I would expect as we continue to see better results, through CCAR that we'll be a little bit more aggressive in our capital repatriation ask. And then there's still a lot of operating leverage. I think is really important focus on what we're accomplishing. If you look at preprovision net revenue, there's operating leverage that you see playing out over the last few quarters, it takes not a whole lot of additional work in that area to start to make a real difference. And then finally, I would say that as we get through the energy cycle, I mean, we've got a very strong reserve. We do think that, that -- I expect we're going to be able to start to lessen the provision as we said earlier. As we come off the other end, I think we're short of real deterioration, kind of significant deterioration than the rest of the economy, the other credit metrics around -- absolute reserves are strong. And I think one of the competitive advantages we're going to have ROEs is going to be provision when we get to the energy cycle that is likely to be pretty low and will also help with our ROE while we continue build this operating leverage that I'm talking about.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Paul, I'll just add to that -- this is Scott. I'll just add to that of the recently focus of much attention and communication about the positive operating leverage is that we really do believe that the basic assumptions about loan growth, redeploying cash
componenttext: Paul, I'll just add to that -- this is Scott. I'll just add to that of the recently focus of much attention and communication about the positive operating leverage is that we really do believe that the basic assumptions about loan growth, redeploying cash, fee income growth, holding expenses flat, the resulting positive operating leverage that we modeled, boost us a long way over a 3-year period to a much more representative ROE. And then you -- depending on what assumptions you want to make about our ability to reduce capital or trim capital, we believe we can get back to the levels Harris described with the plan that we have in place.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd also just note too, I mean, we're clearly been trying -- taking some assets off the table but there's still a fair amount there. And in this rate environment -- I personally find myself asking, scratching my head and saying, 775 basis point premium to
componenttext: I'd also just note too, I mean, we're clearly been trying -- taking some assets off the table but there's still a fair amount there. And in this rate environment -- I personally find myself asking, scratching my head and saying, 775 basis point premium to a risk-free rate, it shouldn't be -- continue to go north of that beyond some back to 12 or something like that. I think we ought to all worry about the industry where the expectations. In an industry where you sort of double the common equity in it for the last decade, I mean the 12% ROEs are what used to be a 24% ROE. And that actually -- I think that could involve stretching beyond the point that is actually prudent. So that's how I think about it.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016

componenttext: Then the second question -- the follow-up question is on the loan that you purchased from the residential side, were they mostly jumbos or were they just conforming-type loans?

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Brad Milsaps with Sandler O'Neill.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Brad Milsaps with Sandler O'Neill.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess I'll ask maybe the first energy question. But just curious, Scott, appreciate your comments on -- it sounds like people became more positive, whether it be your borrowers or investors, we had a nice to move in the oil during the quarter close to 5
componenttext: I guess I'll ask maybe the first energy question. But just curious, Scott, appreciate your comments on -- it sounds like people became more positive, whether it be your borrowers or investors, we had a nice to move in the oil during the quarter close to 50. We've since come back I guess in the low 40s. What level on your mind, I guess, did you start to get concerned again or you think it starts to maybe create more gridlock or -- question maybe some of the deals that have been put in place thus far, just kind of curious, any color around the more recent moved? I know it's been a short period of time but just kind of curious what your thoughts will be there.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Brett. The other thing I would note, we don't comment on it enough but natural gas prices also have rallied significantly since early March. Recall that they declined quite a bit in the fourth quarter of last year and through the middle of March. Oi
componenttext: Sure, Brett. The other thing I would note, we don't comment on it enough but natural gas prices also have rallied significantly since early March. Recall that they declined quite a bit in the fourth quarter of last year and through the middle of March. Oil prices really declined end of January, February, the first part of March and then both have really made a very nice recovery since then. I only note that because recall that in our reserve base lending activity about 50% of the reserve is -- I mean of the borrowing bases natural gas reserves. So you really have to focus on both. But what I would say is that the underwriting that we did in our spring redetermination generally had prices, oil prices, around kind of in the mid to high 30s. And the sensitivity would've been down in the low -- in the high 20s, excuse me, high 20s to 30-ish. And so prices were treated here back to the high 30s. I don't think that would really impact our reserve. If we saw prices go down into the low 30s, high 20s well, then, it might change how we would think about it. But I think there's a lot of room between where we are and that kind of really negative environment. Because fundamentally, the supply and demand curves have improved since 6 months ago, and that's fundamentally driving the price changes. So that would be my comment. I think we feel really pretty good about the reserve base portion of our portfolio. The deficiencies that we experienced in the spring redetermination all have very firm repayment processes associated with them. So we didn't have any big surprises on the reserve base side in the spring redetermination. And it really is just on oilfield service question fundamentally and how long that will go on. And we believe that will go on into next year even with -- even if prices continue to improve.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of John Pancari with Evercore.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of John Pancari with Evercore.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the loan production side, I just wondered if you can elaborate a little bit on where exactly are you intentionally tempering production given concentration limits? I mean, is it all term CRE or is it certain types of CRE underwriting? And is it by mark
componenttext: On the loan production side, I just wondered if you can elaborate a little bit on where exactly are you intentionally tempering production given concentration limits? I mean, is it all term CRE or is it certain types of CRE underwriting? And is it by market? And is there certain concentration measures that you're looking at? If you can help us with how you quantify that.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Michael again. We have very well-defined concentration limits by asset class and types. And there are some historic assets that have proven not to do so well and we obviously have low concentration limits set for those. We're not doing anythi
componenttext: Yes, this is Michael again. We have very well-defined concentration limits by asset class and types. And there are some historic assets that have proven not to do so well and we obviously have low concentration limits set for those. We're not doing anything necessarily to stimulate production in any one of those categories. We think we might be a little heavy on multifamily so we're tempering production there, both construction and term. And I hope that answers your question.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, yes. So -- all right, so what parts of commercial real estate are you still willing to put on the portfolio?
componenttext: Okay, yes. So -- all right, so what parts of commercial real estate are you still willing to put on the portfolio?

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, selectively, any transaction that has a really strong metrics, solid sponsor, guarantor support, good market, deeper MSA that can prove as a worthy takeout source could be -- the retailers is obviously, the online sales has kind of tempered our beli
componenttext: Well, selectively, any transaction that has a really strong metrics, solid sponsor, guarantor support, good market, deeper MSA that can prove as a worthy takeout source could be -- the retailers is obviously, the online sales has kind of tempered our belief and we aren't too excited about putting on a lot of new retail. Industrial is an asset class that is in favor right now to us, especially in the markets that we serve. Hospitality, we have historically deemphasized but we do select hospitality transactions. I would say anything that is horizontal development like A&D, land, lots that isn't -- that aren't associated with homebuilder production and vertical construction is our something -- is an asset class that we're definitely steering away from. Historically, it was in our mix but today and going forward, it's a relatively small piece of the book.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And then sorry if this was already discussed, I might have missed it. But just want to get your overall thoughts on the NIM trajectory here in terms of should we expect that -- given the -- where the new production is coming on and c
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And then sorry if this was already discussed, I might have missed it. But just want to get your overall thoughts on the NIM trajectory here in terms of should we expect that -- given the -- where the new production is coming on and competitive pressures that we see erosion from here or could you see some relative stability?

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, John, this is Paul. I tried to in my remarks is we had some countervailing influences. One is I described you sort of the ongoing grinding of margins that we see. And that obviously adversely impacted net interest margin. In our case though, we are h
componenttext: Yes, John, this is Paul. I tried to in my remarks is we had some countervailing influences. One is I described you sort of the ongoing grinding of margins that we see. And that obviously adversely impacted net interest margin. In our case though, we are helped by the fact that we continue to deploy cash into our highly liquid investment portfolio. And the result of that obviously is no increase in earning assets, the denominator but an increase in net interest income. So net-net, it's helpful to the margin. So what I tried to same to prepared remarks, we're looking at maybe a couple of basis points, we think, over the next couple of quarters. But as you know, as an experienced observer of banks, that can be pretty hard to predict sometimes.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Jack Micenko with SIG.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Jack Micenko with SIG.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: You talked about turning a little bit more cautiously optimistic on energy. Commodity prices are up, I think your exposure's down. But the cumulative charge-off number, it looks like it's been walking up I think you were 75 to 100 in the last year and the
componenttext: You talked about turning a little bit more cautiously optimistic on energy. Commodity prices are up, I think your exposure's down. But the cumulative charge-off number, it looks like it's been walking up I think you were 75 to 100 in the last year and then kind of 100 to 125. And also I think on Slide 18, we're now looking at 125. So is it the frequency issue, is it severity issue? I'm just trying to figure out what has changed there to kind of move that number higher?

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Jack. This is Scott. We have said $75 million to $100 million area. We commented on $125 million today. And then as you noted, our energy net charge-offs were about $75 million through the first half of the year. And we're simply saying we think the
componenttext: Sure, Jack. This is Scott. We have said $75 million to $100 million area. We commented on $125 million today. And then as you noted, our energy net charge-offs were about $75 million through the first half of the year. And we're simply saying we think they will start to go down. We think there'll be less in the second half of the year but it's very hard to know. We don't have a clear line of sight right now to those second half of the year charge-offs. We can see about half of them and then we're assuming others will materialize. So there is an opportunity for a favorable performance relative to the $125 million. The other comment that I think is really important is how does this fit us both Harris and Paul noted in their comment, how does this fit in terms of our overall thoughts about net charge-offs this year. Recall that we guided to 30 to 35 basis points, $125 million to $150 million in net charge-offs.  And clearly, our energy charge-offs are going to be larger than what we thought but we've only had $1 million in net charge-offs on the other 94% of the loan portfolio through the 6 months. And we are clearly going to have less charge-offs than we anticipated there. So we continue to anticipate the same consolidated net charge-off experience that we've guided to. It's just going to be a little more weighted to energy.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think -- I'd just also add. I think -- from my perspective anyway, it's Harris, the most encouraging thing that I'm seeing is we're not seeing new names popping up. The list of deals we expected that we might see some frame basically a year ago hasn't r
componenttext: I think -- I'd just also add. I think -- from my perspective anyway, it's Harris, the most encouraging thing that I'm seeing is we're not seeing new names popping up. The list of deals we expected that we might see some frame basically a year ago hasn't really fundamentally changed. So some of the timing, some extent perhaps even magnitude and in some of these deals has been a little bit different. But we're not seeing new names coming out of the woodwork, and I think that's a big plus in our thinking about it.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: It is. And I would also note that on the -- because the vast majority of our charge-offs on the energy side are coming from the oilfield service fees, recall that we have significant private equity sponsorship with our 70-some-odd service base companies,
componenttext: It is. And I would also note that on the -- because the vast majority of our charge-offs on the energy side are coming from the oilfield service fees, recall that we have significant private equity sponsorship with our 70-some-odd service base companies, our larger service-based companies that we've manned. And to date, last year and 3, 6 months this year, they've injected about $250 million of capital into our borrowers. Just back of the envelope, that would be 15% to 25% in increased equity to those existing the deals, which generally were 50% equity, 50% debt using some broad generalizations here. So we've seen really strong performance from the private equity funds when you think of 15% to 25% equity injection in an 18-month period. And we're strengthening pricing in oil and gas commodity prices, we believe that'll continue.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Esther, we're out of time on that part of the -- so we'd like to take the last few questions but just limit it to one question at this point and we'll try to keep our answers concise also.
componenttext: Esther, we're out of time on that part of the -- so we'd like to take the last few questions but just limit it to one question at this point and we'll try to keep our answers concise also.

I thought that would be your ongoing mix of earning assets that, that would certainly support stable if not an expanding margin. Does that assume that the securities yield stay under pressure in the third or fourth quarter as they were in the second quarter from a prepayment speed?

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's precisely correct. Not only are we buying new bonds, which is hopeful, but the bonds that we do have are prepaying faster. There's premium attached of those months that's decreasing the yield and that happens as you know. And so there's a litt
componenttext: Yes, that's precisely correct. Not only are we buying new bonds, which is hopeful, but the bonds that we do have are prepaying faster. There's premium attached of those months that's decreasing the yield and that happens as you know. And so there's a little headwind there that we're dealing with, in addition to ongoing kind of grinding tighter of credit spreads.

componenttext: I was wondering if you could expand on the compensation comments where you'd say tighter incentive comp is linked to achieving the efficiency ratio target. I guess on mortgage wealth management, that's pretty clear. So my question is how are you driving your commercial bankers to be more efficient? Is it something we can track on the balance sheet, pricing yields or is that also a function of some of the fee businesses, capital markets, treasury, et cetera?

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think what we're fundamentally referring to there is we've got -- we have an incentive plan that covers top roughly 450 or so officers of the company, that is effectively very closely linked to how we do in terms of cost control and continuing to
componenttext: Well, I think what we're fundamentally referring to there is we've got -- we have an incentive plan that covers top roughly 450 or so officers of the company, that is effectively very closely linked to how we do in terms of cost control and continuing to develop for operating leverage, et cetera. But if the cost is -- cost control is just kind of a central theme in how we think about payout some of that plan. So some of you have heard me say before, but I tell all of our people here that every nickel they spend consider -- it's not, not of shareholder money, it's coming out of the wallets of kind of the top 450 people in the company because of the extent that we don't hit those targets, there's funding for that instead of plan is reduced to the point that we do. So there's a very, very tight linkage in that respect.
