componenttextpreview: Well, I guess I'd say in terms of loan growth, I mean, we kind of get a report card every Monday morning. And last week, I was discouraged. This morning, I was encouraged. And it's like seesaw back and forth. It's still a little early in the quarter to ma
componenttext: Well, I guess I'd say in terms of loan growth, I mean, we kind of get a report card every Monday morning. And last week, I was discouraged. This morning, I was encouraged. And it's like seesaw back and forth. It's still a little early in the quarter to make much sense of it.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: And in terms of loan growth rates in general, it's sort of a 5% to 7% growth rate for C&I. The CRE portfolio, we're projecting to kind of grow in the 4% to 5% growth rate range. Even though it softened in the recent quarters, we are still anticipating gro
componenttext: And in terms of loan growth rates in general, it's sort of a 5% to 7% growth rate for C&I. The CRE portfolio, we're projecting to kind of grow in the 4% to 5% growth rate range. Even though it softened in the recent quarters, we are still anticipating growing that. And then we are seeing nice increases on the consumer side this year, principally through our mortgage-related products. So really, we don't need -- the C&I growth rate is very consistent with the mid-single-digit growth rate we need for the entire portfolio.

componenttext: Okay, good, all right. And then secondly, just wanted to ask around the energy reserve. componenttext: I don't recall exactly where. Our energy reserve was probably not too different than our total reserve, so it would have been around 1.60, 1.5 going into the downturn. Now it's at 8%. I tried to provide in my remarks a little bit of a multiyear reconciliation of that. And the guidance that Paul was providing around provision for the entire company really would lead you to believe that we would see moderate releases in that energy reserve.

componenttext: Yes, this is Paul. I'll just add on that, as a reminder, the energy reserve is over 8%. And in fact, this quarter on a dollar basis, there was a little bit of release in energy. But because the decline in the portfolio outpaced that, the energy reserve on the portfolio remained over 8%.

componenttext: No, I wouldn't say that. Sorry if I wasn't clear. The amount of cash we need to hold on to the balance sheet is not a big number, although it's probably going to be in the hundreds of millions and maybe $1 billion. The fact of the matter is, is that the securities we're buying are so liquid that it really minimizes the need for on-balance sheet cash, if that gets to your question.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Maybe a different -- slightly different question. Just you mentioned the premium amortization was a component of the NIM compression. Is that something that, just now that we're at a lower level, is going to -- NIM should remain at that lower level?
componenttext: Okay. Maybe a different -- slightly different question. Just you mentioned the premium amortization was a component of the NIM compression. Is that something that, just now that we're at a lower level, is going to -- NIM should remain at that lower level? Or does any part of the premium amortization next quarter cause some pop upwards in the margin?

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, the premium amortization is due to prepayments on the portfolio as we -- as you know. And there are kind of 2 big chunky parts of the portfolio, one related to our SBA bonds and the other relates to our mortgage-backed securities. Incidentally, they'
componenttext: Yes, the premium amortization is due to prepayments on the portfolio as we -- as you know. And there are kind of 2 big chunky parts of the portfolio, one related to our SBA bonds and the other relates to our mortgage-backed securities. Incidentally, they're both impacted by kind of different macro factors. I will say that the primary factor this time was accelerated prepayments on mortgages. And so you can look at kind of the Refi Index is probably an indication of where that amortization is going. And so what we saw was increased amortization due to increased prepayments on the mortgage-backed securities portfolio. To the extent the yield curve steepens, my expectation would be that those prepayments will slow down, and you would see a corresponding impact on the mortgage-backed securities portfolio. I would also note that there aren't a lot of macro impacts related to the "Brexit" that appear to have slowed prepayments down as we move -- have moved into October.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Jill Shea of Credit Suisse.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Jill Shea of Credit Suisse.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe could you just touch on the guidance around NII and the ability to attain the mid- to high single-digit growth even without a December rate hike? Can you just speak to the confidence there? Is it NIM stability? Is it loan growth? Or is it the cash d
componenttext: Maybe could you just touch on the guidance around NII and the ability to attain the mid- to high single-digit growth even without a December rate hike? Can you just speak to the confidence there? Is it NIM stability? Is it loan growth? Or is it the cash deployment into the securities book? Maybe just dig into that guidance and how we should think about the outlook for the NIM going forward.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure, this is Paul. It's kind of a combination of all those things. As a reminder, we would expect net interest income to be, over 12 months, positively impacted by about kind of $25 million to $30 million for every 25 basis point rate increase. But
componenttext: Yes, sure, this is Paul. It's kind of a combination of all those things. As a reminder, we would expect net interest income to be, over 12 months, positively impacted by about kind of $25 million to $30 million for every 25 basis point rate increase. But it's a big mover [ph]. As we've seen over the course of the last year and you saw this in our PPNR, which Harris noted was up over 20% over the course of the last year, a lot of that's related to improvements in net interest income, and a lot of that is related to kind of our ability to maintain coupon on a loan book. And while we're growing the loan portfolio and then deploying cash and liquidity into the investment portfolio, kind of moving out of assets earning 25 basis points to earning closer to kind of 125 to 150 or more potentially. But also importantly, to the extent we're deploying kind of off-balance sheet liquidity, it continues to lever our capital, which we would expect to continue to grow net interest income. So we feel pretty good about our ability to grow loans, maintain margins, and as you note, redeploy cash in the investment portfolio.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Jill, this is James. I might just jump in and mention that on -- as we look at the book of business, particularly on the commercial loan side, as we look out over the next several quarters, the loans that are maturing have a coupon that is very simila
componenttext: And Jill, this is James. I might just jump in and mention that on -- as we look at the book of business, particularly on the commercial loan side, as we look out over the next several quarters, the loans that are maturing have a coupon that is very similar to the loans that we're producing. So we're not seeing a lot of compression. As a total book of business, our -- the coupon on our loan portfolio only declined 1 basis point, and so you see in the GAAP yield table that the yield on the loan portfolio declined 5 basis points. Only 1 out of the 5 basis points was due to the coupon declining. The rest of it was due to the changes in the way that fees are amortized on that book of business and the FDIC and so forth. So we're really not seeing a lot of compression on the margin side. So Paul talked to the volume side and the margin is probably relatively stable.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's really helpful. And then just in turn, I think you already just touched on some of the securities portfolio adds, but you noted in the slide that you're not necessarily limited by the cash currently on the balance sheet. Can you just walk us
componenttext: Okay. That's really helpful. And then just in turn, I think you already just touched on some of the securities portfolio adds, but you noted in the slide that you're not necessarily limited by the cash currently on the balance sheet. Can you just walk us through how you think about the size of the securities book? Is it a percentage of earning assets? How should we think about the potential securities build over time?

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, the securities portfolio exists, first and foremost, as a source of liquidity for the balance sheet. And historically, we've held a lot of cash for that purpose. And now as noted, we're deploying that into investment securities, highly liquid HQLA, i
componenttext: Yes, the securities portfolio exists, first and foremost, as a source of liquidity for the balance sheet. And historically, we've held a lot of cash for that purpose. And now as noted, we're deploying that into investment securities, highly liquid HQLA, if you will, highly liquid assets as defined by the LCR in order to maintain what is a very strong position as it relates to the LCR. Looking ahead, we use the investment portfolio again primarily for liquidity but also to manage interest rate risk. And as we think about our interest rate risk positioning over time, I think you've seen us slowly decrease that. That is our asset sensitivity. So that process may continue, and so that's kind of a secondary use, if you will. The investment portfolio is a mechanism to add duration to the balance sheet that helps to balance kind of the very short-term, short-duration assets we have with the relatively longer-duration liabilities. So it's really those 2 components that drive the size and composition of the investment portfolio.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from David Eads with UBS.
componenttext: And our next question comes from David Eads with UBS.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe just kind of touching on this balance sheet theme. You saw a really nice increase in noninterest-bearing deposits, and deposits in general seem like they're up pretty solidly. I guess anything unusual going on there? And is the thought to -- in the
componenttext: Maybe just kind of touching on this balance sheet theme. You saw a really nice increase in noninterest-bearing deposits, and deposits in general seem like they're up pretty solidly. I guess anything unusual going on there? And is the thought to -- in the event deposit growth exceeds loan growth that most of that will end up being deployed in securities?

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: My expectation would not be that deposit growth exceeds loan growth, certainly over the medium term. In the near term, as noted, we're deploying our balance sheet liquidity into securities. And so to the extent -- to your question, if that were to happen,
componenttext: My expectation would not be that deposit growth exceeds loan growth, certainly over the medium term. In the near term, as noted, we're deploying our balance sheet liquidity into securities. And so to the extent -- to your question, if that were to happen, it would probably affect the types of products that we're buying on the asset side because of kind of relative nature perhaps or length of time we might expect to hold those securities. But certainly, I would see us continuing to deploy that excess cash into securities.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, this is Scott. The growth in demand deposits is principally a function of just our business banking orientation and our industry-leading Treasury Management product suite. And you'll -- generally, there will be some ebbs and flows in that, but you'
componenttext: David, this is Scott. The growth in demand deposits is principally a function of just our business banking orientation and our industry-leading Treasury Management product suite. And you'll -- generally, there will be some ebbs and flows in that, but you'll generally see growth in demand deposits in the second half of the year. Kind of from the late summer through the end of the year would be a seasonal occurrence that we would expect.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then in the kind of geographic loan growth chart, I see that if you look at the C&I ex-energy, the biggest negative growth market was energy. I'm just kind of curious, will you characterize that as just kind of the same kind of typical or just slowing
componenttext: And then in the kind of geographic loan growth chart, I see that if you look at the C&I ex-energy, the biggest negative growth market was energy. I'm just kind of curious, will you characterize that as just kind of the same kind of typical or just slowing demand? Or was there anything different going on in Texas this quarter?

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, that's -- it's Scott. That's where you would see this principally the majority of this $250 million of energy paydowns.
componenttext: Well, that's -- it's Scott. That's where you would see this principally the majority of this $250 million of energy paydowns.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I was talking about ex-energy, the $86 million of negative growth.
componenttext: Well, I was talking about ex-energy, the $86 million of negative growth.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Oh, excuse me. Yes, yes, I don't -- I wouldn't really comment much on that other than the economy has obviously slowed in Texas, particularly in Houston. And I really should be careful to say it really has not slowed at all in the Dallas-Fort Worth Metrop
componenttext: Oh, excuse me. Yes, yes, I don't -- I wouldn't really comment much on that other than the economy has obviously slowed in Texas, particularly in Houston. And I really should be careful to say it really has not slowed at all in the Dallas-Fort Worth Metroplex. Their job growth is very strong where we have a bank. There's solid growth in San Antonio, the economy there where we have a bank. But Houston particularly, you're seeing activity levels decrease across the board. And so my guess is that's the fundamental driver of those lower nonenergy C&I outstandings.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: And David, this is James. I'll just comment, I'm familiar with some payoffs due to some merger activity. So we don't do a tremendous amount of leverage buyout financing. And so some of our middle-market companies were purchased during the quarter, and tha
componenttext: And David, this is James. I'll just comment, I'm familiar with some payoffs due to some merger activity. So we don't do a tremendous amount of leverage buyout financing. And so some of our middle-market companies were purchased during the quarter, and that was -- that accelerated some of the payoff rates.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Steve Alexopoulos with JPMorgan.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Steve Alexopoulos with JPMorgan.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the company made nice progress over the past year in growing PPNR. That's pretty clear. With the guidance calling for a slight increase in expenses in 2017, what are your thoughts on a more aggressive cost containment program in '17, maybe something si
componenttext: So the company made nice progress over the past year in growing PPNR. That's pretty clear. With the guidance calling for a slight increase in expenses in 2017, what are your thoughts on a more aggressive cost containment program in '17, maybe something similar to what we saw out of Comerica?

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I expect that you'll continue to see progress in terms of headcount and -- I mean, we're continuing to identify opportunities. We're doing a lot of work in terms of process, back office. I think for us and probably for the industry, the pace of bran
componenttext: Well, I expect that you'll continue to see progress in terms of headcount and -- I mean, we're continuing to identify opportunities. We're doing a lot of work in terms of process, back office. I think for us and probably for the industry, the pace of branch closures probably slows, though it won't stop. But I mean, I -- for us, this has been -- we've been at this now for several quarters. We're not likely to do sort of -- bring in a lot of consultants to try and figure out, refresh what we're going to do next. I think we've got a pretty good game plan. I would note, I'll just remind everyone, that we're doing something that nobody else in the industry is doing, and that is we're in the process of replacing all of our core processing systems. We think that, that's actually a really important kind of long-term investment to be making in a digital age that we're in. That's costing us -- it cost us about $35 million this year and about the same next year. At the -- when we come out the other end of this, which is still -- it's kind of 3 years away, but I do expect that's going to create a much simpler back office in this place. And that's where the real opportunity is. And so we're really focused on doing things that aren't just very short term but really reinvent how we do business starting with systems. And so I don't envision changing course but I think we're going to continue to make pretty good progress. And so I think expenses are going to been pretty flat, but you have to run pretty hard to keep flat because you have -- I mean, cost of labor is starting to increase. I mean, we're seeing increases here and there and like I said, a lot of systems work going on. So I think when you keep expenses flat, that'll actually be a pretty good achievement.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2016

componenttext: Yes, there wasn't anything particularly unusual, although there was a significant positive impact we had in problem credits. So -- and one way to think about that is recall that our oilfield services portfolio, which has outstandings of about 600 -- about $500 million that, that portfolio is going to amortize about $100 million a year even in a difficult environment. And so -- and we're seeing that because most of -- as I noted, 90% of our energy credits are performing as agreed, regardless of how we have them classified.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe I could ask this way. Are you seeing some of your more distressed credits get access to the capital markets and use those proceeds to pay you guys down?
componenttext: Maybe I could ask this way. Are you seeing some of your more distressed credits get access to the capital markets and use those proceeds to pay you guys down?

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, the answer to that question is most certainly. We -- I sort of vaguely referenced it earlier, but we had about $200 million of new either private equity injections or capital markets injections into our energy, our oil and gas portfolio companies. Th
componenttext: Yes, the answer to that question is most certainly. We -- I sort of vaguely referenced it earlier, but we had about $200 million of new either private equity injections or capital markets injections into our energy, our oil and gas portfolio companies. That was the largest quarterly increase that we had seen. That number is about $450 million now since January 1, 2015. So $200 million in a quarter is very significant. And I'd say about 40% of that number came from capital markets activities. 50% to 60% came from private equity injections, which -- and we've seen that private equity phenomenon all throughout the downturn. But the public markets have opened it back up to a certain degree.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Ken Usdin of Jefferies.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Ken Usdin of Jefferies.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just one more question on the securities portfolio. Paul, you mentioned a year ago that you'd be buying about $6 billion or so. It looks like you've already kind of gotten to that point, and you're still growing at about $1 billion a quarter. So is that t
componenttext: Just one more question on the securities portfolio. Paul, you mentioned a year ago that you'd be buying about $6 billion or so. It looks like you've already kind of gotten to that point, and you're still growing at about $1 billion a quarter. So is that the kind of pace that we should be expecting to see the book grow? And is there any stopping point where you get to that right level of the book with a combination of securities and adds on the swap side?

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: The answer to that is yes, there is a stopping point and we're not there yet. So to your point, we outlined -- initially, we outlined a plan to move cash into the investment portfolio. As we've done that, I think we recognize the benefits of that, and so
componenttext: The answer to that is yes, there is a stopping point and we're not there yet. So to your point, we outlined -- initially, we outlined a plan to move cash into the investment portfolio. As we've done that, I think we recognize the benefits of that, and so we're continuing to work on that position, if you will. Ultimately, kind of the "stopping point" would most likely be defined by kind of our target asset sensitivity and with a minimum required on-balance sheet liquidity in the form of high-quality liquid assets. And so perhaps as we move through time, we'll be able to give kind of a more certain outlook around that. But I think for the time being, your point is a good one, which is we've kind of achieved what we said we were going to achieve and we're continuing on the path.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And we saw that with your FHLBs up as well, so I guess is that how should we assume it would be largely funded if loans are growing at the same pace as deposits?

componenttext: Yes.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, those were actually relatively short term, and they were there to take advantage of a kind of very short-term, I'll say, anomaly in the capital markets that were related to money market reform that allowed us to kind of pocket a little extra money th
componenttext: Yes, those were actually relatively short term, and they were there to take advantage of a kind of very short-term, I'll say, anomaly in the capital markets that were related to money market reform that allowed us to kind of pocket a little extra money there at quarter-end. So those were not long-term borrowings. But I will say that over time, as we move through cash over time, I would expect us to access the Federal Home Loan Bank system in sort of the normal course of business.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just one quick one on ROE. Got close to 8 this quarter on ROTCE. You talked about a desire to get to double digits. You mentioned previously that you think you could get there with rates in '17. Can you get there without rates in '17? And if not
componenttext: Okay. And just one quick one on ROE. Got close to 8 this quarter on ROTCE. You talked about a desire to get to double digits. You mentioned previously that you think you could get there with rates in '17. Can you get there without rates in '17? And if not, is it possible in '18?

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, look, is it possible? Certainly, but I would say that we'll be in a position, I think, to provide kind of a better kind of outlook and guidance as we get to the December earnings call in January. So there are a lot of things that go into that measur
componenttext: Well, look, is it possible? Certainly, but I would say that we'll be in a position, I think, to provide kind of a better kind of outlook and guidance as we get to the December earnings call in January. So there are a lot of things that go into that measure. As you know, we're really focused right now on improvements to the efficiency ratio, and we're going to continue to be focused on that. Ultimately, an improved efficiency ratio should drive better balance sheet returns, should lead to better ROE. We're also very focused onto the CCAR process, managing our capital more effectively. And because there are 2 components to that, we kind of control the numerator. The denominator is subject to the kind of regulatory CCAR process. It's hard for us to provide a lot of clarity and guidance on precisely when we're going to get there.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Ken, this is James. I just want to jump in. On the outlook for double-digit returns on tangible common equity, I think what we've said was it was more of a 2018 aspirational goal as opposed to 2017. I would just modify the year there and tell you more
componenttext: And Ken, this is James. I just want to jump in. On the outlook for double-digit returns on tangible common equity, I think what we've said was it was more of a 2018 aspirational goal as opposed to 2017. I would just modify the year there and tell you more to come on that.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Marty Mosby of Vining Sparks.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Marty Mosby of Vining Sparks.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wanted to build on Steven's question earlier about the -- as you're right -- seeing the run-off in the energy loans. The graph that I was looking at is Page 9. If you look at the criticized loans in oil and gas to your overall loans in classified to loans
componenttext: Wanted to build on Steven's question earlier about the -- as you're right -- seeing the run-off in the energy loans. The graph that I was looking at is Page 9. If you look at the criticized loans in oil and gas to your overall loans in classified to loans and nonperforming to loans, those are all trending much higher as percentages. But when you look at the actual numbers, when you got back to Page 18, I was surprised to see that the actual levels or dollar amounts went down. So it does seem like there may be more of an exodus of the performing loans versus what we're seeing in criticized or classifieds. So I just wanted to make sure we kind of focus back on that question again just to kind of reconcile those 2 pages.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Marty. Let me -- I was actually going to bring us back to that. It's a fairly technical question. I have the information but it wasn't totally committed to memory. We started the quarter at about $800 million in classified loans and ended the quarte
componenttext: Sure, Marty. Let me -- I was actually going to bring us back to that. It's a fairly technical question. I have the information but it wasn't totally committed to memory. We started the quarter at about $800 million in classified loans and ended the quarter a bit down from there, about $770 million in classified loans. We had about $220 million in what I would call very positive favorable reductions of classified loans either through payoffs or paydowns. I'm not talking about charge-offs, okay? $220 million. That was one of our strongest quarters of positive resolutions. But far more important than that is that the inflow of new classifieds or increase in existing classified oil and gas loans was the lowest inflow, the smallest inflow that we've had since the middle of 2015. So it -- if you want to think about it, we started out with about $800 million in classifieds, with about 25% of those had positive resolutions. And we were not replacing them as fast as they were running off. So...

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then that, if you went from $800 million to $770 million, you positively dealt with $220 million, that means that you had inflows of around $190 million, I guess, is that about right?
componenttext: And then that, if you went from $800 million to $770 million, you positively dealt with $220 million, that means that you had inflows of around $190 million, I guess, is that about right?

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's exactly right.
componenttext: That's exactly right.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So still about equal in the sense of what's leaving and what's coming back as you kind of go through that process. But yet still, like you said, improving from what you've seen before. Paul, I want to ask you on the mortgage-backed securities. I'm t
componenttext: Okay. So still about equal in the sense of what's leaving and what's coming back as you kind of go through that process. But yet still, like you said, improving from what you've seen before. Paul, I want to ask you on the mortgage-backed securities. I'm trying to reconcile again 2 things that seem a little bit contradictory. One is you have no extension whatsoever in duration when rates go up, but when run rates come down, you have cash flows and prepayment. I know that you can't buy some CMOs that are more one-sided and since they don't extend but they do because we're in the early tranches get paydowns, is that what's driving that? Is that there's that hard stop on the extension but yet you have the risk of the prepayments when rates go lower? Is that why that discrepancy is kind of coming out?

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Marty, the -- I guess the trick in our investment portfolio, the part of it that does look a little bit different is that we do have these SBA pools. And these are not -- the prepayments on those are not correlated to rate necessarily. So what we see is t
componenttext: Marty, the -- I guess the trick in our investment portfolio, the part of it that does look a little bit different is that we do have these SBA pools. And these are not -- the prepayments on those are not correlated to rate necessarily. So what we see is they are positively convexed [indiscernible] instead of negatively convexed [indiscernible]. And so in our models, as we run the rate shocks, what we're seeing is that, if you will, the positive convexity of the SBA pools and the negative complexity of the MBS roughly offset each other, which is why you don't see the extension risk in the plus 200 rate environment as disclosed. Is that helpful?

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the netting of that is why you don't get the extension, but on the short end, the mortgage-backed prepayment is what caused you the impact this quarter?
componenttext: So the netting of that is why you don't get the extension, but on the short end, the mortgage-backed prepayment is what caused you the impact this quarter?

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, again, the mortgage prepayments are related to changes in rate in the flattening curve, yes, accelerated prepayments there. That was not necessarily -- there was not a corresponding impact in the SBA pools.
componenttext: Well, again, the mortgage prepayments are related to changes in rate in the flattening curve, yes, accelerated prepayments there. That was not necessarily -- there was not a corresponding impact in the SBA pools.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Gary Tenner of D.A. Davidson.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Gary Tenner of D.A. Davidson.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to hit on the fee side for a second. I recall -- I think it was this past year's Investor Day or possibly the one before, you talked a lot about bringing that fee income contribution up to, I think, 25% as sort of an intermediate-term goal. Ov
componenttext: Just wanted to hit on the fee side for a second. I recall -- I think it was this past year's Investor Day or possibly the one before, you talked a lot about bringing that fee income contribution up to, I think, 25% as sort of an intermediate-term goal. Over the last year, you've made some progress on bringing up, obviously, the customer fees, but the percentage hasn't changed much. I wonder if you can update kind of what you're thinking in there given the relative moves of net interest income versus fees.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Thank you, Gary. This is Scott. First of all, the fee income ratio with the pace at which net interest income is growing because of loan growth and the repositioning of cash, I don't think you're going to see us make a lot of progress in terms of th
componenttext: Sure. Thank you, Gary. This is Scott. First of all, the fee income ratio with the pace at which net interest income is growing because of loan growth and the repositioning of cash, I don't think you're going to see us make a lot of progress in terms of that ratio, just the pure math of it because we're trying to grow our customer fees in the kind of mid-single-digit rate, 5% to 7% range. And net interest income is growing at a faster rate, and may continue to based on the guidance we provided. So the -- I think the more important number we're focused on is just the absolute dollar amount of customer-related fees and total fee income and how that's accretive to earnings. So -- and that number is, again, very nicely a little bit stronger than we even would have expected. So -- and it's across the board, which is really important. It's in our -- workhorse fee income item is Treasury Management. It's about 30% of our $500 million in fee income. It's growing very nicely on a linked-quarter year-over-year basis as well as year-to-date. Our credit card income is growing nicely. Wealth Management, we basically had 2 Wealth Management platforms. We had 2 of virtually everything. We have now gone through the organizational process of creating one business, and it's terrific to see that business growing. The insurance component of that business has been a leader for us as well as just our core investment management business. So good solid progress in Wealth Management after doing a lot of -- making a lot of tough decisions there. Mortgage, as we've noted, is up. Foreign exchange, a nice business for us, is up. Really we're seeing good solid progress across the entire fee income spectrum.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2016

componenttext: And Candice, this is James. I believe we have -- it's John Moran from Macquarie.

componenttext: Yes, this is Paul. A big chunk of that was related to that legal accrual that I discussed. If we see a little better loan growth, that will obviously help us and others around the industry, if we see a little better loan demand. But all in all, we're really pleased with the year that's starting to come to a close, and we appreciate all of your support. Thank you.

I would like to introduce your host for today's conference, James Abbott, Director of Investor Relations. Sir, you may begin.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Esther, and good evening. We welcome you to this conference call to discuss our 2016 second quarter earnings. Our primary participants today will be Harris Simmons, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; Scott McLean, President and Chief Operati
componenttext:
Thank you, Esther, and good evening. We welcome you to this conference call to discuss our 2016 second quarter earnings. Our primary participants today will be Harris Simmons, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; Scott McLean, President and Chief Operating Officer; and Paul Burdiss, Chief Financial Officer.
I would like to remind you that during this call, we will be making forward-looking statements, although actual results may differ materially. We encourage you to review that this disclaimer in the press release or the slide deck dealing with forward-looking information, which applies equally to statements made in this call. A copy of the full earnings release as well as a supplemental slide deck are available at zionsbancorporation.com, and we will be referring to the slide during this call. 
The earnings release, the related slide presentation and this earnings call contain several references to non-GAAP measures, including pre-provision net revenue and the efficiency ratio, which are common industry terms used by investors and financial services analysts. Certain of these non-GAAP measures are key inputs into Zions' management compensation and are used in Zions' strategic goals that have been and may continue to be articulated to investors. Therefore, the use of such non-GAAP measures are believed by management to be of substantial interest to the consumers of these financial disclosures, and are used predominantly throughout the disclosures. A full reconciliation of the difference between such measures and GAAP financials is provided within the published document and participants are encouraged to carefully review this reconciliation. 
We intend to limit the length of this call to 1 hour, which will include a question-and-answer section. [Operator Instructions]
I'll now turn the time over to Harris Simmons.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much, James, and welcome all of you to our call this afternoon to discuss our 2016 second quarter results. On Slide 3 are some highlights for the quarter. Earnings per share increased to $0.44 from a loss of $0.01 per share a year ago. By u
componenttext:
Thank you very much, James, and welcome all of you to our call this afternoon to discuss our 2016 second quarter results. On Slide 3 are some highlights for the quarter. Earnings per share increased to $0.44 from a loss of $0.01 per share a year ago. By using the same adjustments that we used to compute our efficiency ratio, which primarily to adjust for the loss on the sale of our remaining collateralized debt obligation portfolio a year ago, and the preferred stock redemption expense in the second quarter of this year, earnings per share increased nearly 17% over the prior year second quarter. We're pleased with the continued trend of strong increases in pre-provision net revenue, which is the result of solid net interest income growth and adjusted noninterest expense levels that were well controlled and that remain within the parameters of our stated expense initiatives.
Adjusted for the same items mentioned earlier, we achieved positive operating leverage for the fifth consecutive quarter. We're tracking well with our efficiency initiative, with the efficiency ratio declining to 64.5% in the second quarter from 68.5% in the prior quarter. Recall that our goal for 2016 was to achieve an efficiency ratio of less than 66%. We also experienced improved loan growth. The second quarter loans increased 2.6% from the prior quarter. So it was a good quarter for loan growth.
Credit quality is a little bit of a tale of 2 cities. We consistently tried to be very transparent about the credit quality challenges of the oil and gas portfolio through this energy cycle. It remains challenged, and we'll discuss that in a little more detail later. Outside of oil and gas, the loan net charge-offs were only $1 million on a portfolio of approximately $40 billion of non-oil and gas loans. So we get outside of the oil and gas portfolio, we're actually really, really pleased with the quality that we're seeing there.
Turning to Slide 4, our adjusted pre-provision net revenue has improved by a strong 32% over the past year. The adjustments to the GAAP numbers are detailed at the end of the slide deck, with the major exclusion of the effect of securities gains and losses. We have been -- and we've been successful at improving both revenue and trimming expenses. We expect to continue to post continued growth and adjusted pre-provision net revenue, although we expect the rate of growth for the next 12 months to be somewhat less than the very strong 32% we saw this quarter.
On Slide 5, we display our loans and deposits. Relative to the first quarter, we experienced an acceleration of loan growth in the second quarter with loans held for investment increasing 2.6%, as previously noted. Deposit balance has increased an annualized 3.1% from the prior quarter without an increase in the cost of deposits.
On Slide 6, there's a graphical representation of our loan growth by type. The size of the circles represents the relative size of the loan types. We remain pleased with growth in areas that are targeted for growth. Although we've experienced strong growth in termed commercial real estate, we expect growth in that category to moderate going forward. We also expect nonenergy, commercial and industrial loans and residential mortgage loans to experience solid growth to be the primary drivers of loan growth over the next few quarters.
We continue to expect a decline in the national real estate portfolio that we discussed on prior occasions. I might add one additional note regarding overall loan growth going forward. The second and fourth quarters are typically seasonally a little stronger than the first and third quarters. So while we're particularly pleased with the second quarter's growth, we expect more tempered growth in the third quarter.
Moving to Slide 7. We are well on our way to achieving another key measure of our commitment to shareholders, which is to reduce the efficiency ratio at less than 66% for the full year of 2016. As noted, year-to-date, the efficiency ratio is 66.5%; quarterly level was 64.5%. I'd also note that we're achieving all of this while investing substantially in enabling new technology and modernizing our core deposit loan systems, which we expect will provide benefits for years to come and will be a really important competitive strength for us, once we complete these projects over the next 2 or 3 years.
On Slide 8 is our scorecard highlighting the commitments we made to shareholders back in June of 2015. I'm pleased with the progress made in a number of these areas in a relatively short period of time. All of the major initiatives are tracking to the targeted budgets and time lines. I'm pleased to report that we've completed the preferred equity dividend reduction a year earlier than our commitment.
My concluding comment will be regarding credit quality. In previous presentations to investors, I've highlighted the Zions' loan quality is measured by net loan losses that has been superior to most regional peer banks through multiple cycles. This is largely attributable to the collateralized nature of our lending. On Slide 9, my high-level comment on energy lending is that we have turned from cautious to cautiously optimistic. We believe there will continue to be losses in that portfolio, but with our strong reserve, we presently expect to experience average quarterly provisioning for loan losses over the next year at a level that is relatively consistent with that of the second quarter. Excluding energy loans, credit quality is really strong across the company, as noted, and this is true by both loan type and geography. About $40 billion of the $42.5 billion loan portfolio consist of nonenergy loans, and the total net charge-off ratio on that portfolio during the last 5 quarters has a medium -- a median of only 1 basis point annualized Nonperforming assets were stable relative to the prior quarter, and the nonenergy classified loans declined and 90-plus day delinquency has also declined. So some good metrics there.
With that overview, I'll turn the call over to Paul Burgess to review the financial results. Paul?

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Harris, and good evening, everyone. I'll begin on Slide 10. For the second quarter of 2016, Zions reported net earnings applicable to common shareholders of $91 million or $0.44 per share. Relative to the second quarter of last year, net intere
componenttext:
Thank you, Harris, and good evening, everyone. I'll begin on Slide 10. For the second quarter of 2016, Zions reported net earnings applicable to common shareholders of $91 million or $0.44 per share. Relative to the second quarter of last year, net interest income increased about $41 million or 9.7%. Customer-related fees, which is the bulk of noninterest income, improved about 5% from the second quarter of 2015. At $382 million, noninterest expense was lower in the second quarter of 2016 when compared to the year-ago quarter. Although the year-ago quarter included seasonal stock-based compensation, which was incurred in the first quarter in 2016 for this fiscal year. However, even considering this, we continue to make solid progress on our noninterest expense commitment.
Turning to the provision for loan and lease losses. At our last earnings call, we provided an outlook for provisions for the next 4 quarters that were consistent with the first quarter of 2016. Overall, loan losses in the second quarter were roughly in line with that forecast. Also in the second quarter, we observed higher and more stable energy commodity prices, improved sentiment by oil and gas borrowers and sponsors and improved capital markets activity in that industry. However, because we remain cautious on the outlook for losses in that portfolio, we maintain the dollar amount of the oil and gas reserve. The resulting reserve, as a percentage of oil and gas loans, increased slightly as a result of the decline in oil and gas balances outstanding. Additionally, continued improvements in the rest of the loan portfolio and minimal non-oil and gas net charge-off have resulted in lower overall reserve and provision levels in the second quarter when compared to the first quarter.
Slide 11 outlines our recent trends in net interest income, which continued to demonstrate strength in the second quarter. On a year-over-year basis, net interest income was up 9.7% when compared to the second quarter of 2015, driven by growth in loans and in the investment portfolio. The linked-quarter increase was due to several various factors. Most of the increase was due to the strong average loan growth and continued deployment of cash into higher yielding, highly liquid investment securities. 
We remain positioned to benefit from rising rates, particularly short-term rates, as shown in the box at the bottom right-hand side of the slide. Although we have deployed a substantial amount of cash into securities and loans, the interest rate risk characteristics of both the assets, combined with continued deposit growth, have resulted in a somewhat stable interest rate sensitivity position. Using the midpoint of the range shown, a 25-basis-point rate increase would improve annual net interest income by $25 million to $30 million, we expect. As a reminder, our performance objectives that were initially communicated in June 2015 assume 1 additional 25-basis-point federal funds target rate increase in December of 2016. Recently, the market was priced again about a 50% chance of this occurring, approximately back to where it was prior to and up substantially from the low of 8% in the wake of the Brexit vote.
Slide 12 provides additional information regarding our active management of the investment portfolio. We continued to add high-quality liquid securities to our investment portfolio in the second quarter, reflecting the need for a permanent high-quality liquid asset position in order to manage our balance sheet liquidity more effectively and in light of the liquidity coverage ratio rule. Our efforts to build out the investment portfolio are expected to add revenue in the current and downside economic environments when compared to holding liquidity in the form of cash. During the second quarter, the available-for-sale investment portfolio increased $879 million on average when compared to the prior quarter. We continue to exercise caution with respect to the impact on overall balance sheet interest rate sensitivity as we purchase fixed-rate investments, and with respect to the duration extension risk inherent in that investment portfolio.
The mortgage-backed securities we are adding are relatively short in duration, right around 3 years, with duration extension risk being only about 0.5 year, if rates increase by 200 basis points. The duration of the entire securities portfolio, including our floating-rate SBA securities, is about 2.7 years today. If rates were to rise 200 basis points across the curve, our model estimates that duration of the portfolio would extend only slightly to 2.8 years. A minor footnote to the disclosure on this extension risk. In previous iterations, we assumed a static prepayment rate for the SBA securities. In April, we made a change to the model to assume dynamic prepayment speed assumptions and these securities behave in the opposite fashion when compared to residential mortgage-backed securities. We believe the SBA securities are expected to generally experience higher prepayment as rates rise, thus, in some sense, offsetting the minor extension risk continued within the residential mortgage-backed securities portfolio.
Another key component of net interest income, the rate or yields of the investment portfolio and the loan production can be found on Slide 13. This slide breaks down key components of our net interest margin. Top line is the loan yield, which expanded 2 basis points from the prior quarter to average 4.16%, and this was primarily attributable to commercial real estate loans that matured or repriced during the quarter. The securities portfolio yield dipped this quarter largely due to increased premium amortization, which was in turn due to higher prepayment rates. We expect some additional pressure on the securities portfolio yield in 2016 as a result of the recent increase in mortgage refinancing activity. 
At the bottom of this chart is a line depicting our cost of funds as a percent of our earning assets, which continues to be quite low, at 16 basis points, and was stable relative to the prior quarter. The combination of all of these components and the continued deployment of cash into better yielding, highly liquid investments resulted in a 4-basis-point increase in the net interest margin this quarter. Although we do expect increased premium amortization from the residential mortgage-backed securities portfolio as well as increased refinance activity on a portion of our residential loan portfolio, we estimate the effect on the net interest margin to be less than 5 basis points in the near term. This may be offset by continued shift of cash into loans and securities.  Over the longer term, as cash balances reach minimal levels, we expect to require additional funding for loan growth, although most sources of funding would result in lower incremental margins per dollar of loans produced. The overall effect could be a modestly compressing net interest margin, but a continued increase in net interest income.
Turning to Slide 14, and noninterest income. Because of the seasonality of results, we think year-over-year comparison is most relevant. We were able to increase customer-related fee income by 5% over the year-ago period. The areas experiencing the most significant growth include treasury management, which was up 8%; wealth management, which was up 9%; and mortgage up 16%. Notably, in the current quarter, there was a $1.7 million gain in the loan sales and servicing line item that is related to the increased valuation of mortgage loan held for sale at quarter-end. That valuation increase was attributable to the sharp decline of interest rates at the end of the month of June. As such, we do not expect that specific gain to be repeated, although we continue to expect relatively strong growth in our mortgage business.
Noninterest expense on Slide 15 declined 4.3% from the prior year, and if adjusted for items such as severance as displayed in the GAAP to non-GAAP table in the back of our slide deck, the decline was 2.6% from the year-ago period. Although I will note that about half of that improvement is due to the timing of stock-based compensation, which we have had discussed previously. For 2016, we are tracking to an adjusted noninterest expense level that is consistent with our stated goal of less than $1.58 billion. Relative to the prior quarter, the decline in noninterest expense was predominantly due to a decline in salary and benefits. As you know, in the first quarter, we incurred seasonal expenses, which taper or are not present for the balance of the year. Specifically, severance declined $3 million, stock-based compensation and retirement plan matching declined $9 million and payroll taxes declined $4 million, when we observe the second quarter compared to the first quarter.
Turning to Slide 16. We're pleased to announce last Friday that we are actively pursuing our capital plan. To that end, the board has increased the quarterly dividend rate by 33% to $0.08 per share. Additionally, we have been authorized to initiate our common equity buyback plan, which calls for $180 million over the course of the next 4 quarters. By doing so, we will be actively managing our capital to a lower level in order to align the capital structure to the risk profile of the company. We expect this to enhance return on equity as well as accelerate the growth rate of earnings per share.
With that, I'll turn the call over to Scott McLean to discuss energy lending and recap our commitment to investors. Scott?

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Paul. On Slide 17, we show on the left side of the slide, the oil and gas loans broken down by upstream, services and other. Other is essentially midstream and downstream. Energy loan outstanding balances decreased about $73 million from the pr
componenttext:
Thank you, Paul. On Slide 17, we show on the left side of the slide, the oil and gas loans broken down by upstream, services and other. Other is essentially midstream and downstream. Energy loan outstanding balances decreased about $73 million from the prior quarter, with declines principally in upstream and services -- and the services portfolio, offset by a small amount of growth in the midstream portfolio. Parenthetically, you will note on Slide 22, that energy loan commitments declined more than $270 million from the prior quarter and are down $875 million from the prior year.
Looking at the problem loan metrics again on Slide 17 for the oil and gas portfolio. Classified energy loan balances increased about $99 million during the quarter. This compares to a $194 million increase in the -- in quarter 1, which indicates a slowing trend in new problem outstanding. Also of note, and easier to see on Slide 22, criticized balances actually declined $20 million from Q1. Finally, nonaccrual loan balances were flat relative to the prior quarter. It may be helpful to understand that the vast majority of criticized, classified and even nonaccrual loans are still current on their contractual payment.
On Slide 18, regarding our loss expectations. If oil were to hold in the mid-40s or higher, we currently expect energy losses for 2016 to be approximately $125 million. We expect most of these losses to come from our services portfolio, an area where a substantial number of borrowers remain challenged. Although oil and gas net loan losses may remain elevated, we anticipate the second half of 2016 to be less than the first half of 2016 in terms of energy net charge-offs, which were approximately $73 million in the first half of 2016. Most of the balance of the loans that we've flagged as high risk for loss already have substantial specific reserves set aside against them. As Harris noted earlier, we have improved our outlook on energy to what we would describe as cautiously optimistic. Our conversations with borrowers and sponsors suggest that sentiment has improved, as you can imagine, given the increase in the underlying oil and gas commodity prices. Also highlighted on this slide, we maintained our energy loan loss reserve relatively flat, equaling slightly more than $200 million and more than 8% of outstanding balances. We consider this a very strong reserve, particularly relative to various measures of problem loans and loss expectations.
If you turn to Slide 19, this is the last of our key objectives and our commitments -- and our fundamental commitment to shareholders. We're fully committed to achieving the positive operating leverage we described. And I think at this point, with more than 30% year-over-year growth in PPNR, we can declare that our actions are making a very noticeable difference. We remain committed to the substantial simplification of all operational processes and upgrading our technology systems, which will position us with perhaps the most modern loan, deposit and customer information infrastructure in the United States. When complete, this investment will significantly simplify our back office, provide data on a real-time basis to bankers and customers, improve our new product time to market, position us well to more aggressively adopt enhanced digital capabilities and many additional advantages. Regarding the capital with which shareholders have entrusted us, we're targeting much more substantial returns on capital than what can be seen today, and we are tracking well with those goals as discussed earlier.
Regarding returns of capital, we're pleased with the non-objection by the Federal Reserve to increase our return of capital to shareholders. Finally, we are absolutely committed to our history of doing business with local communities, with a local community bank approach. Perhaps the best acknowledgment that our commitment to doing business locally really is the strategic differentiator is the superlative results we received again this year in the nationwide survey conducted by Greenwich research. As you know, we received more awards for the highest level of national distinction than any other bank, and we are only 1 of 4 banks that have performed at the industry-leading level since the initiation of this survey approximately 8 years ago.
Paul, with that, I'd like to turn the call back to you.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Scott. Slide 20 depicts our outlook for the next 12 months, relative to the most recent quarter. We are downgrading our loan growth outlook to moderately increasing from increasing due primarily to internal decisions to constrain some of the comme
componenttext:
Thanks, Scott. Slide 20 depicts our outlook for the next 12 months, relative to the most recent quarter. We are downgrading our loan growth outlook to moderately increasing from increasing due primarily to internal decisions to constrain some of the commercial real estate growth we have recently experienced. Although the quality of what we're producing remains very strong, we are going to remain disciplined in our concentration of risk management, avoiding too much in any one geography, loan type or single vintage. We expect net interest income to increase in the mid to high single-digit growth rate, driven primarily by loan growth and additional growth in the investment portfolio. Given the right market conditions, we may also add interest rate swaps to assist with the reduction of our asset sensitivity. Although our efficiency target includes the assumption of one additional quarter point rate hike, we believe we can achieve a mid- to high single-digit growth rate in net interest income without an increase in the target federal funds rate.
We expect a quarterly provision for credit loss, which includes the provision for both funded loans and unfunded loan commitments, to be roughly stable relative to the second quarter, assuming no significant adverse change in market conditions. We expect that customer-related noninterest income, which includes dividend income and securities gains and losses, will increase slightly to moderately as we continue to focus heavily on this area. We continue to be encouraged by the efforts of our teammates to manage our cost of doing business. Our collective efforts allow Zions to remain on track toward our goal of adjusted noninterest expense at less than $1.58 billion for 2016.
For the next 4 quarters, we expect noninterest expense to run approximately similar to the first half of 2016 annualized, with similar seasonal variation in the first quarter of '17, as was seen in the first quarter of '16. The effective tax rate for the second quarter returned to its more typical level. Recall in the first quarter, we recognized a one-time tax credit. We expect our effective tax rate to be in the range of 34% to 36% over the next 12 months. We expect preferred dividends to continue to decline. With the successful tender completed in the second quarter, preferred dividends are expected to be approximately $45 million over the next 12 months.
This concludes our prepared remarks. Esther, would you please open the line for questions?

componenttext: This is Michael Morris. I'm the Chief Credit Officer. I'll comment on that briefly. The term commercial real estate growth that we saw in Q2 was driven partly by slower paydowns, some conversion of construction to term loan and other value-add transactions in the income property space, all of which are well underwritten safe BCRs, well-defined and lower LTVs, equity and transactions. So it was a little bit unusual, but we're very satisfied with the credit quality of that particular portion of the loan growth and CRE.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Geoff, this is James Abbott. I just might add a couple. We looked at the underwriting statistics of the production for the quarter, and just in terms of a general comment, the average loan to value is in the mid-50s and the average debt service covera
componenttext: And Geoff, this is James Abbott. I just might add a couple. We looked at the underwriting statistics of the production for the quarter, and just in terms of a general comment, the average loan to value is in the mid-50s and the average debt service coverage ratio would be about 2x coverage. So a very good underwriting statistics on the growth that we did see. But again, as we mentioned earlier, we're concerned about too much in one vintage or one particular loan classification.

componenttext: Geoff, this is Scott. I would also note that geographically, it was really a nice dispersion across California, Arizona, Nevada and Washington, with a small modest amount of growth in Texas on the term side. But the term has been pretty well-balanced across the portfolio.

componenttext: I thought it was a pretty solid performance on the fee side. Is it still early yet? Or are you starting to see some results from some of your initiatives there? And excluding the loan sale valuation thing you talked about, is this a pretty good base to build off going forward here?

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Joe, this is Scott. And yes, I think our initiatives are showing nice progress. Our treasury management activities are still -- it's our largest fee income stream. It's about 30%, and it's growing in the mid- to high single-digit rates, which is really go
componenttext: Joe, this is Scott. And yes, I think our initiatives are showing nice progress. Our treasury management activities are still -- it's our largest fee income stream. It's about 30%, and it's growing in the mid- to high single-digit rates, which is really good for that business. Our other bank card products, business card, consumer card are growing at high single-digit rates, which is -- we've talked about repeatedly over the last couple of years, basically trying to get the same sort of penetration in our other markets that we currently achieve for those products in Zions First National Bank, our bank in Utah. And then, wealth management, which we've been concentrating on. It's growing high single digits. Mortgage, the fee income component is not growing, even though our volume -- origination volume is up. It was up 30% last year. Our origination volume will be up about 30% this year. But we are keeping more of that on the books. And consequently, it's not having the fee income benefit that we thought it would. But those would be just some things I would highlight.

componenttextpreview: It was a modest purchase with a really strong correspondent that we have a lot of respect for. We are, as you know, still significantly underweighted on exposure to 1- to 4-family. And even though we're originating really nice volumes with our mortgage in
componenttext: It was a modest purchase with a really strong correspondent that we have a lot of respect for. We are, as you know, still significantly underweighted on exposure to 1- to 4-family. And even though we're originating really nice volumes with our mortgage initiative, we thought at least having this as an alternate source was -- is a good thing. The yields are significantly higher than what we could buy into our investment portfolio. And the credit statistics are on par with our own originations with yields principally on par with our own originations. So it's just a real nice relationship, and we'll probably continue it at a very modest pace. But it's clearly not a key driver of our results.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: If you're speaking about the -- if the question is about the cash balance, I would expect to continue to whittle that down. Ultimately, as I said in my prepared remarks, I do expect for us to get into a position where we are going to incrementally go out
componenttext: If you're speaking about the -- if the question is about the cash balance, I would expect to continue to whittle that down. Ultimately, as I said in my prepared remarks, I do expect for us to get into a position where we are going to incrementally go out and need to fund loan growth. When that happens, then you can assume that our cash balance has reached sort of its low point and the point that we're most comfortable with.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Then just a quick one on the mortgage book or -- strictly in the HELOC. It looks like you kind of had broad-based growth in all the geography. I'm curious, is that just kind of a function of growing off of a low base? Or is there something you guys
componenttext: Okay. Then just a quick one on the mortgage book or -- strictly in the HELOC. It looks like you kind of had broad-based growth in all the geography. I'm curious, is that just kind of a function of growing off of a low base? Or is there something you guys are doing to generate that loan growth, whereas most of the peers are struggling to generate your own growth there?

componenttext: Yes, that's been kind of the focus of a very specific campaign to -- that's been focused on all the lines of credit. So I think we're seeing results of that kind of marketing push.

componenttext: On the expense side, you guys are doing a good job and certainly marching towards that sub-$1.58 billion this year. Just wondering what kind of line of sight you have on that at this point. And if you think you can maybe have more flexibility than you would have originally thought on any increases that would have come after this year?

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016

componenttext: Right. This is Scott, and we -- basically, what we said was $1,580,000,000 for this year and slightly increasing in 2017. And I think fundamentally, we feel we're going to be able to stay fairly close to the $1,580,000,000 next year as well. So we're continuing to find new ways to reduce expense in light of -- and fund those areas of growing.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016

componenttext: And has...

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016

I mean, I -- to the extent that it's north of $1,580,000,000, there won't be much in excess of that. Maybe better than it, but I think it's a little early still.

headline: Zions Bancorporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
